dialogues.speaker: CELEBRANTS
dialogues.text: (shouting, in unison) ..Hip hip hooray!!! Crystal clanking. Corks popping. Behind the TOASTMASTER, an enormous BANNER: "Victory to the Union"

dialogues.speaker: WASHINGTON, D.C.
dialogues.text: A grand CELEBRATION instantly denoting prestige and influ all powerful and all for Union.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is he here, yet?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No. But half his cabinet is. REVEAL: FREDERICK AIKEN, now 28, aged a bit by events, jo again by NICHOLAS BAKER, now minus his leg. Another hotsh WILLIAM HAMILTON, is present too. They've all had a few. Aiken scans faces. Notes players. POWER BROKERS abound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's Interior...the Postmaster... INSERT: GRAYBEARDS, as Aiken identifies the members of LINCOLN'S CABINET, Like positions around an infield.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Treasury...Navy...and War

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Secretary Stanton, where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aiken points to EDWIN STANTON, 50, imperious, chest lengt beard, eyes concealed behind tiny, gold-rimmed glasses.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'd give my eye-teeth to meet him. Aiken begins to beeline towards Stanton, then stops.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Aren't you coming?

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Just like that?

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: Are you mad? You can't approach Edwin Stanton without an introduction.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Watch how it's done. Unless, you'd prefer to meet him too? Baker nods. Aiken moves to help his one-legged friend.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: I can do it myself.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Like hell, you couldn't walk straight with two. A BOOMING VOICE catches Aiken from behind.

dialogues.speaker: BOOMING VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Aiken, I've been to creation and back looking for you. Aiken turns toward a familiar voice.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Baker, Hamilton... May I introduce the distinguished Senator from Maryland -- Mr. Reverdy Johnson. REVEAL: REVERDY JOHNSON, early 50's, a thorn in anyone's side. Blind in his left eye. Very southern.

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: A great honor, Senator

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slurred from drinking) May I say, sir...you were our first I mean, our finest Attorney General.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Honor's mine, gentlemen. You've done this nation proud. Glad to see y'all are enjoyin' this evenin'. Reverdy Johnson winks at Baker with his good eye.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Country needs you boys more than ever to put it back together. Reverdy Johnson spots several GRAYBEARDS passing by.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, would you excuse us a moment? They're some folks I reckon' my new associate ought to meet. The Senator leads Aiken away. Hamilton watches with envy.

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: I reckon Fred has to if he's to be considered seriously.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Yes, Hamilton, some of us do have to work for a living...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverdy ushers Aiken inside the club's inner sanctum line with PORTRAITS of its past luminaries JEFFERSON, MADISON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite a turnout.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Victory is like shit to flies, Freddie. One whiff is all it takes. sarcastically) . Mr. Secretary, such a delightful surprise. REVEAL: EDWIN STANTON puffing furiously on a FAT CIGAR.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY OF WAR
dialogues.text: Life's full of â€˜em, Senator

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Frederick Aiken. Of course, you're familiar with our venerable War Secretary, Edwin Stanton.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. It's a great pleasure, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand you took two bullets at Gettysburg, Colonel, and never quit the field. The pleasure is mine Stanton warmly clanks Aiken's champagne glass. Aiken beam

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: We can always use a loyal man like you over at the War Department.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: My godson works for me now, Ed. It's time to heal the nation -- not wage war.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Depending on whose side you're on.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: One needn't be a Yankee to be for Union same as you.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Well then, I dare say, the enemy is never far from hand. An AIDE hands Stanton a NOTE. Stanton reads it.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Is everything alright? ; _ STANTON ; President Lincoln sends his regrets -- seems Mrs. Lincoln made other plans. ...The SOUND of laughter.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: As TWO ACTORS perform the farce, "Our American Cousin." O is dressed as a Victorian DANDY; the other, as an eccentr BACKWOODSMAN. The setting is an English drawing room. ...The SOURCE of laughter

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: As ABRAHAM and MARY LINCOLN enjoy the performance. The PRESIDENT tilts back-and-forth in a crimson rocking c The FIRST LADY lovingly drapes her hand across his knee. A couple in their twenties, MAJOR RATHBONE and CLARA HARR are seated nearby. ...A P.0.V on the LINCOLNS and their GUESTS.

dialogues.text: Revealing the P.0.V is coming from a small PEEPHOLE in th door leading to the President's BALCONY BOX.  6. A Sliver of light barely illuminates the viewer's identit JOHN WILKES BOOTH, 26, Strikingly attractive and attired. As Booth spies on President Lincoln...

dialogues.speaker: MATCH CUT TO
dialogues.text: ...A TALL MAN with a BLACK FELT HAT, spying too.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: Only, he's watching the ENTRANCE to a stately, three-stor MANSION from across Washington's Lafayette Square. Private Residence o Secretary of State Frederick Seward The Tall Man pulls a BOWIE KNIFE from beneath his felt ha a REVOLVER from his overcoat, and crosses the street. He mounts the mansion's FRONT STOOP and rings the door BE A BUTLER answers...

dialogues.speaker: MATCH CUT TO
dialogues.text: ...The DOOR swinging open. Only, instead of the Tall Man entering, it's a SMALL MAN, wearing a BEAVER SKIN CAP...

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: ...And instead of the Mansion's entrance, we're now insid plush HOTEL LOBBY, crowded with GUESTS. The Residence o Vice President Andrew Johnson The Short Man shuffles UNCOMFORTABLY amidst all the opule his EYES flashing to a CLOCK on the WALL, which reads: 10:15 P.M. ...The sudden POP of a CHAMPAGNE CORK.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: As Baker opens a fresh bottle. Aiken has rejoined his mat

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Good to see the last four years did someone good. REVEALING: the stunning CATHERINE MORGAN, early 20's.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello, Catherine.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Too grown up to call me Katie anymore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the one who's grown up. Catherine warmly greets Baker, Hamilton. Glances at Aiken

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Johnny Reb' get his tongue?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: How are you, Katie?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Not a letter from you in 18 months. I should ask how you are?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: We didn't see much I wanted to share.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: (re. Hamilton) Bill wrote me twice a month.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: That so?

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: Just checking in with the home front.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: One's imagination wanders when you haven't a word. ; AIKEN ; ; Might we have one now - in private? Catherine nods, turns back to Baker and Hamilton.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Sure good to see you, boys. Aiken escorts Catherine away, fingers clasped. Hamilton looks on with envy. Baker pops a cigar. LIGHTS a match...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: ...The startling BANG of a pistol. An EXPLOSION, like the deep POP of a heavy, paper bag. Th a BURST of smoke. And finally, a THUD, bullet against bon

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: As Lincoln's rocking ceases, and his chin pitches into hi chest. MARY LINCOLN clutches his neck to keep him upright Booth stands a few paces behind -- a brass DERRINGER in h right hand; a DAGGER in his left. Major Rathbone dunges for Booth. But Booth swings his dag wildly, piercing the Major's left arm. Booth vaults over the FRONT RAILING, and clips his SPUR the BUNTING, causing him to land awkwardly on the STAGE b SNAP! His left ankle fractures badly above the in-step. H limps across the stage, stopping just long enough to YELL

dialogues.speaker: BOOTH
dialogues.text: Sic Semper Tyrannis! Revenge for the South. Then, rushes past dazed ACTORS, and escapes into the WING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as Booth's TALL ACCOMPLICE bursts out the FRONT DOOR his hands dripping with blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACKING through the house to REVEAL what's left behind: -- First, the Tall Accomplice 's BLACK FELT HAT tipped on side, at the bottom of the staircase; -- Then, a GUARD, coughing blood, writhing along the stai -- Followed by an ARMY AIDE, badly hurt and bleeding, slu on the second floor landing; -- Next, SEWARD'S SON, alive, but unconscious with a frac skull, inside a bedroom doorway; -- And lastly, SECRETARY of STATE FREDERICK SEWARD, in be gasping for air and bleeding, from a near-fatal facial ga

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Booth's SHORT ACCOMPLICE, with the BEAVER SKIN HAT, is fr with fear on a bar stool, his eyes leaden with drink. A SOLDIER casts a suspicious glance his way, causing the fearful Associate to flee out the front door, as we CUT T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as Aiken is placing an ENGAGEMENT RING on Catherine' finger. Baker, now piss drunk, celebrates his mate's new union by drinking champagne from his artificial leg. A SOLDIER rushes past knocking Baker's leg out of his han

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: What the hell? Suddenly, Secretary Stanton is whisked away under heavy security. Followed by several more party-goers. Hamilton approaches Aiken and Catherine, his face ashen.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: What is it, Bill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've attacked Lincoln - and the Secretary of State too. Aiken registers the shock. As Baker tries to locate his l amidst the tumult, we DISSOLVE TO -- A near-riotous crowd assembled outside PETERSEN HOUSE, a townhouse across the street from Ford's Theater Torches ablaze. Vengeance on many lips. We TRACK with Union MAJOR H.W. SMITH inside --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, sloped BEDROOM adorned with pastoral prints. It an unspectacular setting for a spectacular end. DOCTORS, CABINET MEMBERS and a PRESBYTERIAN MINISTER surr PRESIDENT LINCOLN, who is laying diagonally across a bed far too short -- his bare feet angling over the edge. The only sound is of Lincoln's near-final gasps. Major Smith passes a PHYSICIAN carrying a bundle of bloodstained towels. Smith continues down the HALLWAY, in An adjacent SITTING ROOM, now functioning as a WAR ROOM - SEVERAL ACTORS, still in costume, are being interrogated. Major Rathbone is trying to console his fiancee, Clara Ha Her clothes are soaked with Lincoln's blood. Major Smith surveys the chaos -- revealing EDWIN STANTON in charge. Stanton beckons him inside a CLOAK ROOM.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR SMITH
dialogues.text: It was the actor, John Wilkes Booth.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Are you certain?

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR SMITH
dialogues.text: They all know him from the theater Pointing to the ACTORS being interrogated in the other ro

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: What about the other assassins?

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR SMITH
dialogues.text: The only name mentioned so far is an acquaintance of Booth's -- a young man named, John Surratt.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: What do we know about him?

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR SMITH
dialogues.text: Twenty-one years of age. Lives here in the city with his family. Mother runs a boardinghouse. That's it.  10.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: I guarantee he's a Confederate. Find him. Find all of them. (a beat) I want this city closed down. Nothing leaves Washington without my authorization. No trains. No boats. If any one of these assassins gets South of the Potomac or up into Canada, he'll never be found. Major Smith exits. Another AIDE approaches.

dialogues.speaker: AIDE
dialogues.text: Sir, the Vice President wishes to pay his respects.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: He may leave that hotel only when I say it's safe to do so. The Aide nods, begins to exit.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calls out) And keep him away from the liquor. He's liable to drink himself into a stupor with fright! MARY LINCOLN lets out a piercing wail from the adjacent r FULL SCREEN: On President Lincoln's motionless FACE accompanied by more screams. PULL BACK: to reveal the screams are coming from a LOCOMO whistling into the night, wrapped in black bunting. Linco face is actually a PORTRAIT fixed to the front of the tra Lincoln's COFFIN is inside.

dialogues.speaker: BEGINS
dialogues.text: As the train builds speed, we INTERCUT between: LINCOLN'S DEIFICATION -- Newspaper headlines chronicle th 1700 mile funeral procession from Washington, D.C. to Springfield, Illinois, his hometown and inal resting plac "40,000 in the Rain in Cleveland"..."300,000 at Independe Hall"..."Half a Million Along Broadway" STANTON'S REIGN of TERROR -- The ROUND-UP of the alleged ASSASSINS. Ford's Theater is chained shut; DOZENS are arrested in saloons, churches, outhouses and homes. BOOTH is cornered inside a BURNING FARMHOUSE. He is shot and killed. Another accomplice, DAVID HEROLD, surrenders. The FINAL IMAGES shown are of -- A slender three-story TOWNHOUSE along a residential stree All appears peaceful. No sign of the hysteria beyond. Suddenly, the FRONT DOOR bursts open.  11. SIX SOLDIERS escort a MYSTERY WOMAN, 45, down the front s while her DAUGHTER, 22, is restrained by several troops. The Mystery Woman is placed inside a JAIL CELL. The DOOR slammed shut behind, plunging her world into darkness.

dialogues.speaker: FADE TO BLACK
dialogues.text: FADE UP: On the AMERICAN FLAG

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: A_ glimpse of the unmistakable CAPITOL DOME, its American flag still flying at half-mast for Lincoln.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aiken races inside the ROTUNDA, nearly knocking over an ELDERLY SENATOR in his path. He sprints across STATUARY HALL, past the busts of our Founding Fathers. Aiken continues down a long HALLWAY lined with Senate off a stack of legal briefs virtually spilling out of his han Finally, he enters through an enormous OAK DOOR bearing t brass inscription: United States Senator (Maryland) Reverdy Johnson He finds REVERDY JOHNSON already long in wait.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Mornin', young man. Nice of you to show up.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: My sincerest apologies, Senator. I was just finishing the land conveyance you requested. The Senator performs a cursory review.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: You've been up all night on this?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Most of it, sir.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Plus some carousing with your mates?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Just a bit.  12.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: I appreciate your enthusiasm, Freddie. I just hope you haven't run yourself ragged, nor forgotten the Assassins' Trial begins tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: No one's talking about anything else. My mates and I hope to squirrel a seat.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Well, you've 'squirreled' a chair instead.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: How's that, sir? The Senator hands Aiken a stack of papers.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: I'm trying the case. You'll be assisting -- my second chair.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: But I thought the government was planning a military court-martial.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Indeed. Secretary Stanton picked himself nine generals to serve as judges -- all for Union and all riends of the late President.

dialogues.speaker: REVEALING
dialogues.text: buttoning

dialogues.speaker: REVEALING
dialogues.text: fastening INT. U.S. the MILITARY COMMISSION, preparing for trial -- their Union uniforms, pinning on their medals. REVERDY JOHNSON (V.O. In fact, he's chosen one of Lincoln's pallbearers to head the Commission. the bearded and bespectacled GENERAL HUNTER, 62, his pearl-handled saber to his hip.

dialogues.speaker: CAPITOL
dialogues.text: As Aiken and Reverdy Johnson continue their conversation through the hallway of the Capitol.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: If it's a military trial, won't the War Department be handling the prosecution?

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Stanton's put his most trusted in charge of the case -- the Chief Adjutant General, Joseph Holt.  13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVEALING Edwin Stanton's devoted aide-de-camp, JOSEPH HO 56, as he devises a strategy with the War Secretary. The corner features a shrine to Lincoln from Ford's Theat Lincoln's rocking chair, top hat and coat -- blood-staine

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Aiken and Reverdy descend the steps, which are now lin with folks hawking LINCOLN MEMORABILIA -- death portraits supposed locks of hair...

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Then, what are we to do?

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Defend one of the eight.

dialogues.speaker: KEN
dialogues.text: One of the Assassins?

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Alleged, counselor. Reverdy Johnson holds up a NOTE.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I received a letter this morning from the lady, the one with the boardinghouse... a Mrs. Mary... The Senator searches the note for Mary's last name. Aiken is quick with the answer.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Surratt.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: She says I once helped her late husband on a tax matter.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: But you don't recall?

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Truth is I don't remember ever laying eyes on her late husband or her. But she's from Maryland too...

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Sir, the government believes her son, John, was Booth's right-hand.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: If they suspect her son, then they ought to try him.  14.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I've heard they have 250 agents out looking for him. Senator, you don't Know her. But you're still defending er?

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Young man, it matters none if I've heard of Mary Surratt -- or her son. She's entitled to a defense. So, I shall defend her! Reverdy continues onward as Aiken remains frozen in place

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mary Eugenia Jenkins Surratt...

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: As we REVEAL -- MARY SURRATT, 45 -- dressed from head-to- in black, her face concealed by a heavy veil. (She is the Mystery Woman shown earlier being led from her home.)

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You are charged with conspiring, aiding and abetting... GENERAL HUNTER, 62, reads from parchment, his saber dangl by his side. He is surrounded by the members of the MILIT COMMISSION, nine grizzled Union vets, high-ranking all.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: The late John Wilkes Booth -- and his Confederates... SEVEN 'CONFEDERATES' are revealed beside Mary Surratt as each name is called. They are seated inside a raised PRISONERS' DOCK. All are in their twenties or early thirt

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER, (CONT'D.)
dialogues.text: David Herold, Michael O'Laughlin, Edward Span fer, Dr. Samuel Mudd Samuel Arnold, George Atzerodt and Lewis Payne... (NOTE: Lewis Payne is readily identifiable as Booth's Tal Accomplice; George Atzerodt as his shorter one.)

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In a treasonous plot to murder President Abraham Lincoln; Vice President Andrew Johnson; and Secretary of State William Seward... The PACKED courtroom stirs with each charge. Hastily converting a BARRACKS into a courtroom inside the prison for security reasons, the chamber measures only 55 feet x 20-feet with an 11-foot high ceiling. The WALLS ar freshly white-washed. All FOUR WINDOWS are barred.  15. The PRESS and JUDGES are seated at long TABLES cutting th room lengthwise. The GALLERY (by invitation only) are cra in at the rear. ARMED SOLDIERS are stationed throughout.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER, (CONT'D.)
dialogues.text: Pursuant to special orders #211 and #216, does the accused wish to offer a plea? The veiled defendant is frozen with fear.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What say you, madam? Guilty or not. Mary Surratt removes her veil revealing a handsome face.

dialogues.speaker: . MARY SURRATT
dialogues.text: I am innocent.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: Of all charges?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. I most certainly am.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: In that case, as each defendant has entered a not guilty plea, we'll begin with the woman first -- the United States versus Mary Surratt. General Hunter looks to the PROSECUTION table positioned advantageously by his side.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Major Holt, please proceed. Joseph Holt rises to begin, his chest laden with medals. is surrounded by a HALF-DOZEN ASSOCIATES.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Just a moment, your honor Reverdy Johnson rises directly in front of Mary Surratt. Frederick Aiken, his lone associate, remains seated besid

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: What is it, Senator?

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: I wish to request an adjournment.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: An adjournment! We just got here. Even the LAWYERS defending the other prisoners seem shock

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: The defendant has been in custod for over a month. But wasn't allowed to contact counsel until yesterday. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've still not been permitted to meet with her.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH HOLT
dialogues.text: Your honor, a delay will only serve to prolong the nation's sorrow.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: My learned colleague, you've had four weeks to prepare your case. No doubt, assisted by the entire War Department. I believe the defendant is entitled to equal consideration.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: Senator, our fellow citizens must be allowed to put this tra edy to rest. The sooner we dispose of this case, the better for everyone.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Everyone but my client.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: Proceed, Major. Holt rises.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: In that case, I move for termination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Termination! Aiken turns to the Gallery spotting Baker, Hamilton and Catherine. Aiken looks as if he'd rather be anywhere else

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: On the grounds this trial is unconstitutional! jehe, allery stirs) The defendant is a civilian entitled to a public trial before a jury of her peers. Not a military court- martial.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH HOLT
dialogues.text: Military courts adjudicated matters involving civilians throughout the war.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: May I remind the distinguished Major the war is over. Moreover, the civi. courts in Washington remained open throughout the entire conflict. And continue to be, as we speak  17.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH HOLT
dialogues.text: And may I remind the Senator, the Attorney General affirmed the legitimacy of this proceeding: Holt reaches for a DOCUMENT, which he reads aloud.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEPH HOLT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "Persons conspiring to assassinate the President -- the Commander -in- Chief -- are considered enemies of the State. And shall be judged by a military tribunal, as would soldiers belonging to a hostile force."

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: "Soldier!' Surely, no member of this Commission recalls a figure as lovely as this under his command? The Senator playfully draws gattery Ss physique in the ai prompting laughter from the galle

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: Senator, you will mind the horror which summons us.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, we all mourn the loss of our most cherished leader. But, in our grief, let us not betray our better judgment and execute a reign of terror. MAJOR GENERAL HARRIS, a member of the Military Commission shouts out with a heavy New England accent.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HARRIS
dialogues.text: "Reign of Terror.' How dare you!

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Every right-minded citizen desires the punishment of those responsible. But one must be judged accor ding to the law -- not as passions see fi

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: Senator, I assure you this tribunal will make every effort to protect the rights of those on trial. But, all Americans have the right to feel safe and secure.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: None of us is safe when a citizen can be dragged from her home, held without charge and denied access to counsel -- merely on a suspicion? Another Commission Member, MAJOR GENERAL KAUTZ, mocks Rev Johnson's southern accent. Kautz is a New Englander.  18.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL KAUTZ
dialogues.text: "Mearlay onah suhspicion.' Sounds to me like the enemy is among us. I recall Maryland was not among our most loyal states during the War. I think its Senator ought to certify his allegiance to this court. BRIGADIER GENERAL HOWE chimes in with his Philadelphia ac

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HOWE
dialogues.text: I quite agree. Make him sign.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: I have served this nation as its Attorney General. That is certification enough. General Kautz holds up a CONTRACT.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL KAUTZ
dialogues.text: Nevertheless, Senator. We may require counsel to sign this oath of loyalty as prescribed by Congress.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: I_am a member of Congress! The branch of government empowered to authorize military tribunals like this.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: Our authorization comes from the War Secretary, Edwin Stanton -- by order of the President of the United States.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Had our founding fathers desired tyranny to prevail, I'm sure they'd have intended for the President and his War Secretary to have such indiscriminate powers. (seething) But they drafted a Constitution with laws limiting power, not trusting in human nature to limit itself -- precisely for times like these: (losing his temper) When our leaders claim to be serving the People... when, in fact, they're only serving themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Gallery erupts. The Prisoners beat iron against wood. General Hunter slams his gavel, repeatedly.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: Order...Order...SILENCE! Order is barely RESTORED.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This court will stand in recess. Senator. In chambers!  19. Off Aiken woefully glancing at his Mates, then at Catheri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prison CORRIDOR outside the generals' CHAMBERS is nea RIOTOUS -- rabid REPORTERS, excited SPECTATORS, and the l Moments later, Reverdy Johnson appears in the hallway wit Aiken in-tow. The inquisitive PRESS converge in a frenzy. Johnson pulls Aiken into a BACK STAIRWELL to escape the hoards. A SOLDIER bars anyone else from following. As Aiken trails his boss upstairs, his face is filled wit panic. The pair are in mid-conversation.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: ..But you can't be serious.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: As serious as the charges against our client.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: But defending her? ME!

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: She doesn't stand a chance with a Southerner like me representing her She needs a Yankee colonel like you.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Yes, but --

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: -- You'll do fine, son. Our nation still has never executed a woman.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: This nation never considered a woman, or aman for that matter, capable of murdering the President. I'm sorry but I can't take on this case.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: "Course you can, boy. They taught you somethin' at Harvard, didn't they?

dialogues.speaker: ATKEN
dialogues.text: I mean, I won't (off Reverdy s glare) I won't defend he Not someone who murdered my Commander -in-chief. TwO SOLDIERS descend the stairs past Aiken and Reverdy. They are guarding an attractive, unidentified WOMAN, 22. She's just overheard Aiken and stares him down. Aiken uncomfortable, waits for her to pass before continuing.  20.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: With all due respect, sir, I'll gladly find you a rebel to represent her.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: No court in the Union would judge that woman fairly with Confederate counsel.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Most folks I know wish for her what happened to Booth.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: No doubt you'd gladly pull the trigger yourself.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I'd hardly be alone. Aiken points to a CROWD outside the PRISON WALLS -- Linco DEVOTEES holding shrines to Lincoln.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look at Lincoln now! Remember how so many used to hate him. Now, no one dares utter a word against him, let alone defend his murderer

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Alleged, counselor. AIKEN ; You don't honestly believe she's innocent?

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: 'Til proven otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I will not betray my country, sir. Nor my friends who died in battle defending it. The pair now stand directly in front of the COURTROOM DOO

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: I'm not suggesting you betray your allegiances. I'm simply asking, rather, telling you to uphold your oath ee an attorney and do your job! eat I demand nothing more. And I assure you, neither your mother or father would've accepted anything less! Aiken wavers.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Sir, I don't see how I can possibly walk in there.  21.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Son, sometimes a man must be willing to 'walk' on faith alone. A beat as we begin to hear...

dialogues.speaker: HOLT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The conspirators attempted what the confederacy could not accomplish in at FULL SCREEN: On Aiken listening to Holt's opening argumen

dialogues.speaker: HOLT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: To destroy our nation by striking at our chain of command -- targeting not_only our President, but the next in line: his Vice President and Secretary of State. (Aiken looks distressed) That a woman - a mother with children - built the nest where this vile conspiracy was hatched, operating a safe-house for the assassins to meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL BACK: To reveal Mary over Aiken's shoulder. Both loo equally panicked but for different reasons.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Makes Mary Surratt as guilty of this crime as John Wilkes Booth himself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A UNION SOLDIER escorts Aiken across the prison grounds - FORTRESS surrounded by BRICK WALLS topped by ARMED SENTRI Just beyond the high walls JAMES CREEK, the foul smelling repository for much of washington" s waste. Blanketing the courtyard is a TENT ENCAMPMENT housing the soldiers, who are guarding the prisoners on trial. Aiken crosses through the encampment. SOLDIERS gather and stare. Some salute Colonel Aiken. Others turn their backs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We continue with Aiken and his armed escort down a long CORRIDOR lined with CELLS -- Each cell is packed with PRISONERS. Some faces are famili the ACTORS being interrogated after Lincoln's assassinati They are still wearing their costumes, now in tatters. Off Aiken's look of confusion, the Guard offers up --

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: The Witnesses, sir.  22.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: How long have they been here?

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Coupla months. Aiken is escorted through a pair of huge IRON DOORS. As h continues down a SECOND STORY CATWALK, we REVEAL -- The CONSPIRATORS' CELLS, eight in all. Inside each cell Aiken discovers the same horrifying sight -- a PRISONER, solitary, head covered by a CANVAS HOOD, no slot for seei barely a hole for breathing. Legs and arms are chained to IRON BALLS. Wrists are separated by piercing METAL MANACL

dialogues.speaker: IKEN
dialogues.text: Is all this necessary?

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: According to orders.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Whose?

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Secretary Stanton, sir Aiken lingers momentarily to ponder, then continues towar the FINAL CELL at the end of the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CELL DOOR number 200 swings opens as Aiken steps inside. MARY is crouching on all fours, chained like a barnyard animal. Though not forced to wear a hood, her ANKLETS and WRIST CUFFS are painfully attached. STRAW is spread benea her; a BUCKET for bodily functions is nearby. The Guard remains at the door

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Thank you, private. That'll be all. The Guard doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This meeting is confidential.

dialogues.speaker: _ GUARD
dialogues.text: Sorry, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Where's the Senator? Aiken turns toward Mary.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Ma'am, he's instructed me to handle your case.  23.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Is there a problem?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No disrespect, Mister...

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Frederick Aiken.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Mr. Aiken, how many years have you?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I'm a month past 28.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Young man, you're barely older than my son.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: The Senator would not have placed me in this position unless he had complete confidence in my abilities.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I take it then you've handled cases like this before?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Ma'am, there's never been a case like this before.

dialogues.speaker: MARY,
dialogues.text: But, you have defended others? Aiken is silent.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I see they've left nothing to chance.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I take it then you'd prefer to conduct your own defense? A beat. Off Mary's silence, Aiken opens his notes.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Very well. I understand you own a boardinghouse at 604 H Street, is that correct?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Yes. Aiken awaits more information. Mary offers none.  24. Ma'am, all I know about you is what I've read in the papers. And what they're reporting isn't flattering. Mary grudgingly.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I moved there a year ago with my son and daughter after my husband passed away.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: The conspirators were frequent visitors to your boardinghouse, were they not? Aiken doesn't even bother to call them alleged conspirato

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: As were many others.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: But, you don't deny having been acquainted with John Wilkes Booth or the other prisoners behind bars?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No, sir. I do not. (sternly) Mr. Aiken, my husband died a drunk leaving me with loads of debt. I had no other way to support my family, except by renting rooms to boarders. I considered those men customers, nothing more. / AIKEN ; ; Did you 'consider' their sentiments?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I did not inquire as to their "sentiments,' sir.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: What about yours, ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I am a Southerner by birth, a Christian by belief, and a devoted mother above all else. And I am NO assassin!

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Ma'am, your freedom will depend on far more assurance than that.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Well, then you tell me what I should say to those Generals?  A beat. 25.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Nothing. The rules prohibit you from testifying in your own defense. I suppose you know of someone else who would? Your son, John, perhaps. Any idea where he might be?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I do not. Even at 21, Mr. Aiken he's still my baby. My son will be kept out of this.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: That won't be easy, ma'am. He's on the wanted poster.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How about his roommate, Louis Wiechmann? Shall I call on him to testify?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Louie is like a member of my family. I don't want any harm coming to him on account of me.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Is there anyone I can call upon to give your version of events? MARY _ ; ; Who are they calling to give their version?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: The Government is not revealing its list of witnesses, or the evidence it plans to use against you.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: They can't do that, can they?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: This is a military proceeding in which the Government can do just about anything it chooses. Of course, it makes preparing a defense more difficult.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Of course. But what difference does it make? Even these failing eyes of mine can see those Generals made up

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: their minds -- just by the way they were looking at me.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: "Looking" at you?  26.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Just like you, Colonel. A GUARD appears with Mary's dinner, hardly appetizing. Ai heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I must go.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Mr. Aiken (Aiken stops) I haven't a word from my daughter since they put me here. Would you check on her for me? Please. He reluctantly nods.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Aiken. I see you've got a spark of human feeling in you after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three-story townhouse seen during the round-up of the alleged assassins. Aiken climbs the front stoop and knock A Union SOLDIER is posted outside her door. Aiken feels a PRESENCE behind -- NEIGHBORS spying from WI and DOORWAYS. Aiken flips his collar to conceal his ident Finally, the boardinghouse DOOR opens.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Anna Surratt? REVEALING: ANNA SURRATT, 22 -- a beautiful young woman wh had to grow up very fast.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My name is Frederick...

dialogues.speaker: ANNA SURRATT
dialogues.text: I know who you are, Mr. Aiken.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Then you know I'm representing your mother.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA SURRATT
dialogues.text: I was under the impression you could not -- or rather, "would not". Aiken now places her from the stairwell inside the courth

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry you heard that. It was meant to be a private conversation. Aiken nervously glances back at the Neighbors.  27.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Are you afraid or just embarrassed to be seen with me, Mr. Aiken?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Your mother asked that I check on you.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: If you will be so kind, please tell her not to worry. She begins to close the door.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Actually, I was hoping to get a look inside. He begins to enter. She momentarily blocks his path, then reluctantly steps aside so he can enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Aiken enters the boardinghouse, he surveys the scene.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Are you the only one here?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Business tends to slow down when there's a soldier stationed out front day and night for my "protection".

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I'll take that as a "yes"?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yes. Aiken moves from room-to-room -- each strikingly cozy and familial. DAGUERREOTYPES of the Surratts line the mantels

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: (under his breath) It's perfect.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Pardon.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Sorry, it's nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Please, do tell. Aiken says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Aiken, I'm sure I've heard much worse in the past month.  28.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Very well. I was thinking this would be the perfect place to conspire to overthrow the government.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No one would ever suspect, right? Aiken doesn't know what to make of Anna.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: May I take a look upstairs? Anna knows why Aiken is here. Without missing a beat --

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: My brother's room is the third on the left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aiken ascends the narrow STAIRCASE up to the SECOND FLOOR then crosses down a short HALLWAY. He enters a small BEDR with two single beds, a desk and dresser inside. Aiken begins to carefully search the bedroom -- underneat the beds, the desk, then inside the DRESSER. He finds undergarments, rolled socks...and, finally, a slip of PAP Just as he pockets the paper, Aiken is startled from behi

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Find what you were looking for? Aiken quickly recovers. Rises.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Louis Wiechmann shared this room, correct?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: That's correct.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Have you seen him recently?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No, I haven't. Did you see much action? Anna is staring at Aiken's UNIFORM.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: A bit.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Kill any on our side? A beat.  29.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Miss Surratt, do you have records indicating who stayed here? A registry? A book of accounts? (no reply) Do you want me to help your mother or not? We hold on Anna, as we CUT TO -- FULL SCREEN: On a FLOORBOARD being pried loose

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: As Anna produces a REGISTRY from beneath the floorboard. She hands it to Aiken.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Anything else you're hiding?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Such as?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Your brother to start. (silence) If you know where he is, I need to know. Is that clear?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Do you have siblings, Mr. Aiken?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I thought not. Suddenly, there is a tremendous CRASH -- Glass sprays across the floor Aiken dives on top of Anna, placing them nose-to-nose. A large ROCK rests beside them, inscribed in blood-red:

dialogues.speaker: DIE REBEL DIE
dialogues.text: Aiken pulls himself off Anna, races OUTSIDE revolver draw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aiken turns to the Guard outside the door, still standing place as if nothing has happened.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Who did that?

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Did what, sir? You're telling me you didn't just see someone throw that rock  30.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Guess I missed it, sir. Aiken gets it. He returns back inside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aiken commands Anna, his gun still drawn.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Pack up. I'm getting you out of here.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I'm not going anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: It's not safe for you to be here all alone. Anna calmly picks up the rock, and walks it across the ro

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I've managed thus far. She places the rock on a shelf, steps back revealing a sm pile of similar rocks.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Let's go. I will arrange for other accommodations. ANNA ; ; A cell at Arsenal Penitentiary? No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I will not have it on my conscience should something happen to you.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Would you please holster your weapon, Colonel. Off Anna remaining resolute, we CUT TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Aiken now prepares Louis Wiechmann's bed for sleep.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Breakfast is at seven. Supper at six.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: This is only for one night. I'll have a new guard posted out front tomorrow. As Anna starts to exit, she calls out.  31.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You're on your own for lunch.

dialogues.speaker: FADE TO BLACK
dialogues.text: Remain in DARKNESS and SILENCE for several beats... indic the passage of time... then the SOUND of a SLAMMING DOOR. Aiken LIGHTS a lantern as we --

dialogues.speaker: FADE UP
dialogues.text: Aiken, startled AWAKE from a deep sleep, tries to make ou the VOICES coming from downstairs, accompanied by BOOTS clomping across hardwood floors. He rises from Wiechmann's BED, heads toward the noise --

dialogues.speaker: STAIRWELL,
dialogues.text: Tiptoeing downstairs to the --

dialogues.speaker: GROUND FLOOR,
dialogues.text: The voices grow louder as he nears the PARLOR DOOR, which slightly ajar. Aiken creeps forward, trying to peek insid Aiken's POV: of a HALF-DOZEN MEN crowded around a table. Anna is serving them coffee. Aiken inches closer to get a better look. The FLOORBOARD buckles beneath in the spot where Anna hid the registry. The creak of the floorboard silences the voices inside. Suddenly, the DOOR swings open on Aiken. He is frozen in place.

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What kept you, Freddie? We've been waiting a long time. Aiken's expression turns to shock as we reveal the speake identity -- JOHN WILKES BOOTH.

dialogues.speaker: PRESENT TIME
dialogues.text: Aiken wakes with a start from his BAD DREAM. His brow is soaked with sweat, concern etched across Aiken's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The atmosphere outside the prison is part-carnival, part- VENDORS hawk SOUVENIRS and REFRESHMENTS, while an angry M eagerly awaits the first witness in Mary Surratt's trial.  32. They are carrying PLACARDS calling for the prisoners' hea A life-size EFFIGY of Mary Surratt hangs from a lamp pole

dialogues.speaker: MARY SURRATT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How is she?

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: Mary leans across the bar to confer with Aiken. The other prisoners on trial are seated beside her.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Your daughter is... fine. She's looking forward to the day you come home.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It's nice of you to say -- even if you don't think that day is coming any time soon.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: In the matter of the United States v. Mary Surratt... The Prosecutor, JOSEPH HOLT, announces to the court. HOLT. ...the People call as their first witness -- Lieutenant Louis Wiechmann. LOUIS WIECHMANN, 22, marches in, PATRIOTISM personified - resplendent in Union blue. He settles confidently into th WITNESS BOX, at center, as the BAILIFF stands ready. Aiken leans over to Mary.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Why would the prosecution be calling him?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF
dialogues.text: Take this Bible in your right hand. Now repeat after me. Mary looks at Wiechmann, who, in turn, looks away.

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF/WEICHMANN
dialogues.text: (responsively) The evidence I shall give before this Court, shall be the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth. Major Holt approaches the witness.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Wiechmann, are you acquainted with the defendant, Mary Surratt?  33.

dialogues.speaker: WIECHMANN
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, I am. I attended divinity college with her son, John.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Until recently you resided at the boardinghouse owned by Mrs. Surratt. Isn't that correct?

dialogues.speaker: WIECHMANN
dialogues.text: That is correct, sir. Holt gestures to the prisoners' dock

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Were any of those prisoners ever present in her home?

dialogues.speaker: WIECHMANN
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Those five to the right. Pointing at the five furthest to the right -- HEROLD, ARN O'LAUGHLIN, ATZERODT and PAYNE.

dialogues.speaker: WIECHMANN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They were 'present' many times.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: At whose invitation?

dialogues.speaker: WIECHMANN
dialogues.text: Her son's.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Objection!

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Objection? Aiken rises, but tentatively.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Uh, yes, there's no way of knowing... I mean no foundation John Surratt even knew these men -- let alone invited them. And since Mr. Surratt's whereabouts are_unknown at this time, the question calls for speculation.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: Mr. Surratt's absence from this roceeding is Mr. Surratt's problem. bjection overruled. Continue, Major

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ou Aiken sits down.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Was John Wilkes Booth a frequent guest of John Surratt's?  34.

dialogues.speaker: WIECHMANN
dialogues.text: Indeed. But all the Surratts adored him. John. His sister, Anna. And their mother, too. Wiechmann glances at Mary.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Were there ever meetings at the boardinghouse involving Mr. Booth?

dialogues.speaker: WIECHMANN
dialogues.text: Many. Sometimes lasting two, three hours. And always in secret, behind closed doors.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Did you ever see Mary Surratt object to these meetings?

dialogues.speaker: . WIECHMANN
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Or to the presence of those men? Pointing at the prisoners. Wiechmann and Mary's eyes meet, then Wiechmann looks away

dialogues.speaker: WIECHMANN
dialogues.text: No, I did not. She appeared to welcome them.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Thank you, Lieutenant. Thank you very much. That'll be all for now. Wiechmann rises and begins to leave. Aiken is fumbling through his notes. He seems lost.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How long did you say these â€˜secret meetings' lasted? Wiechmann stops in his tracks. Returns to the witness box

dialogues.speaker: WIECHMANN
dialogues.text: At least, two...three hours.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Yes, that's right. Finally, Aiken looks up from his notes.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, if you were timing them, Lieutenant...then, I suppose, these "secret meetings' weren't actually a secret kept from you.  35.

dialogues.speaker: WIECHMANN
dialogues.text: I knew about them, sir. But, I had no knowledge of what they were about.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: That's because you never attended any yourself?

dialogues.speaker: WIECHMANN
dialogues.text: Exactly!

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: And why was that?

dialogues.speaker: WIECHMANN
dialogues.text: I thought them suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: "Suspicious'! So then, you did know what they were about?

dialogues.speaker: WIECHMANN
dialogues.text: No, sir. I did not.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Then why were your suspicions aroused?

dialogues.speaker: WIECHMANN
dialogues.text: By the snatches of rebel conversation I overheard in the hallways. And by their frequent whisperings.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Well, in that case. Why didn't you immediately report your 'suspicions' to your superiors at the War Department?

dialogues.speaker: WIECHMANN
dialogues.text: My suspicions weren't of a fixed and settled nature.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: "Fixed and Settled.' Were you instructed to use those words?

dialogues.speaker: WIECHMANN
dialogues.text: Absolutely not. Aiken ponders a moment, then sits down.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: If there's nothing else, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Uh, I do have something else, sir. Tell me, Mr. Wiechmann. Tell us. Have you ever been to Richmond?

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Objection.  36.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I merely wish to know if the Lieutenant has ever visited the capital of Virginia - and Confederacy. General Hunter nods for Wiechmann to answer.

dialogues.speaker: WIECHMANN
dialogues.text: I don't recall. Aiken withdraws the slip of PAPER -- the one he pocketed night before at the boardinghouse.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Perhaps, this train receipt will refresh your memory. It indicates passage to Richmond, and has your name on it.

dialogues.speaker: WIECHMANN
dialogues.text: Yes. That's right. I considered continuing my divinity studies there after the war. I plan on becoming a minister.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: A noble calling, indeed. At what institute in Richmond did you think of enrolling?

dialogues.speaker: WIECHMANN
dialogues.text: The name?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Yes, Lieutenant. The NAME!

dialogues.speaker: WIECHMANN
dialogues.text: Well, ah...

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Objection!

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: There is no academy of the kind in Richmond, is there, sir?

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Objection, your honor!

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Perhaps, you visited Richmond for another purpose entirely?

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: The question is argumentative.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I'll withdraw the question. Lieutenant, you worked for the General in charge of rebel prisoners, did you not?  37.

dialogues.speaker: WIECHMANN
dialogues.text: Yeah, so?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: So perhaps, a distinguished clerk like yourself knew information.

dialogues.speaker: WIECHMANN
dialogues.text: What sort of 'information'?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Of the sort that might've been of divine interest to many rebels within the capital of the Confederacy. | ; HOLT . Objection, your honor! The witness is not on trial here. The prisoner, LEWIS PAYNE, yells out from the dock.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS PAYNE
dialogues.text: He ought to be!

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: Objection allowed. The witness is not on trial.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Sir, I am simply trying to establish theâ€™ credibility... or rather, the lack of credibility.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Objection!

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: Colonel Aiken, you are incriminating the witness.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: "incriminating the witness"! The Lieutenant shared a room with John Surratt. I think it reasonable to conclude Mr. Wiechmann might know a thing or two about this plot to assassinate our President.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: what the Colonel is entirely irrelevant!

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: Counselor, unless you have something more pertinent to ask, the witness will stand down. ; AIKEN ; No, sir. No. I have nothing more "pertinent" to ask. Your honor "concludes"  38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A discrete BRASS SIGN is all that identifies the entrance Illuminated by GAS LANTERNS, it says all one needs to kno about the elite, all-male SOCIAL CLUB inside: The Century Club - A Gentleman's Preserve -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aiken enters the smoke-filled room. A HALF-DOZEN youn HOTSHOTS, including Baker and Hamilton, are playing poker

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: Someone should tell the Colonel he's got on the wrong uniform.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I thought we're permitted to dress down in here, if no lady is present.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Fred's right.

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: My mistake then. I just thought the Colonel traded his blues for gray. Several laugh at Aiken.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Is Treasury now hiring arselickers or did they make an exception for you, Bill? 'Cause after I'm done making a name for myself in the trial of the century, I'll need to protect my rear. The men start laughing at Hamilton.

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: That name is Judas. Hamilton rises. Squares off with Aiken.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Knock it off, Hamilton. Aiken, sit down and join the game.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I've got to prepare for trial.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: You've got time enough for a drink. Hamilton's buying. Aiken reluctantly takes a seat. Baker deals Aiken in.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, Freddie. Tell us. How did you know?  39.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: "Know"?

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: That the Lieutenant was lying. That there's no divinity schoo in â€œall of Richmond.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: You bluffed?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: And he folded. Several chuckle aloud with the notable exception of Hamil who refuses to join in any adoration of Aiken. At that instant, SECRETARY STANTON passes by the door. Stanton holds a_ menacing gaze on Aiken for several momen before exiting frame. Hamilton observes the exchange.

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: Appears the Secretary doesn't care much for your cards! HOLD ON: Aiken looking visibly troubled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aiken, still concerned, confers with Reverdy Johnson, who reviewing the previous day's TRIAL TRANSCRIPT.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: He did not look pleased.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Your cross wasn't exactly what Stanton's kangaroo court had in mind. I'm sorry I wasn't there to enjoy it. Reverdy smiles. Aiken does not.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Wiechmann would've said anything to save his hide. But it still doesn't justify Mary Surratt befriending Booth or the others.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: The makings of a case, but hardly proof beyond a reasonable doubt. AIKEN ; What about those "secret meetings" Wiechmann testified to?  40.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Louis Wiechmann is a liar. You practically said so in court.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Wiechmann is just the start. Who knows what else they've got on her

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Exactly. _'Cause Stanton is keeping it under lock and key -- in violation of every known rule of evidence.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: If the Secretary's so out of line, why are we the only ones saying so? Not one court in the nation has objected to this tribunal. And the public supports it ten to one.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Because everyone's scared to death. You did read Cicero at that fancy school of yours? Aiken nods.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Inter Arma Silent Leges.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: "In time of war, the law is silent." (a beat) But the war is over.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Stanton intends to keep it alive for as long as he sees fit. Reverdy pushes a newspaper in front of Aiken. HEADLINE re Stanton warns of future Rebel Plots: Poisoning Nation's Water Supply, Spreading Smallpox & Firebombing Cities

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fear is the most potent weapon in the Secretary's arsenal.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Who's to say any of this won't happen? The unthinkable already has. 600,000 men slaughtered on the battlefield. Our President murdered while in office. The world has changed -- and so must we.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Don't be so eager to throw away Mary Surratt's rights. One day, you may need them.  41.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Sir, I appreciate your confidence in me. I really do. But you should find someone who gives a damn if her rights are violated. I don't. Not after what she did.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: You're right, Fred. I can't expect you to care. I'll tell you what: if you prove to_me beyond a reasonable doubt she's guilty, I'll take you off this case.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Are you serious, sir? Reverdy nods. Aiken smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think it'll be that easy?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the SUN beats down on the prison walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aiken enters and finds Mary, to his_surprise kneeling in prayer before a Catholic priest, FATHER WALTER, late-30's

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Pardon me, Father. I wish to confer with the prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Speak freely, Mr. Aiken.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Alone, if you don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: All things are naked and open unto the eye of the Lord.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER WALTER
dialogues.text: Quite all right, Mary. I must be going anyway. See you in a week.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Thank you for visiting, Father walter Your words were most comforting. Father Walter departs. Mary puts aside her Bible, removes her reading glasses.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Search me, and know my heart (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. 42.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Try me, and know my thoughts. And see if there be any wicked way in me.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: The Lord knows the way of the wicked, and the way of the wicked will perish.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You know your Proverbs, young man.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: My father read them to me each night.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Said it contained all I needed to know. Good versus evil, right versus wrong.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Is your world so black and white?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: When it comes to doing what's right.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: So, what is it you wish to know?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Why Booth and his associates were constantly in your home?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I ran a boardinghouse, Mr. Aiken. Forgive me if I chose to fill it with boarders.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I checked your registry. There's no record Booth ever stayed with you. Fact is, he checked into the National whenever he came to town. So, why was he a regular in your home?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I suppose my son invited him. They were friends.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: A famous actor like Booth engaging your son out of friendship. I find hat hard to believe.  43.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Ny Johnnie is no less a gentleman than you, Mr. Aiken, and capable of forming acquaintances in society.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I've read all about your family's acquaintances, ma'am. About your late husband contributing to the Confederate cause; about your eldest son, Isaac, fighting for the rebel army down in Texas; and about your 'Gentleman' Johnnie, too.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What about him?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: He made quite a sum as a Confederate courier carrying rebel secrets across enemy lines. So, I know damn well what your family's capable of, and I know you're not telling me the truth.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Then you know what I do not.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: You were despondent over losing the war, and would've done anything to save the Confederacy -- including using your own son, John.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Honestly, Mr. Aiken.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: So, you arranged a meeting with Booth -- figuring he'd befriend your son because of what John knew -- what expert couriers know --

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: And what might that be?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: The best escape routes out-of-town.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I take it there's more.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Your son was supposed to lead the other assassins to freedom that night. Except, your son was the only one that got away.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Quite persuasive, Mr. Aiken. Except my son was up in Canada at the time of the assassination.  44.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Where exactly in Canada was he?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Exactly, I don't know. Off Aiken's DISBELIEF.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Does your mother know your exact whereabouts at all times? Silence.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Very well. Mary withdraws a wrinkled POSTCARD from inside her corset

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My son sent this to me from Canada, the same day as the assassination. Proves he was out-of-town that night.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Proves nothing. He could've had it sent. Aiken drops the card. It flutters to the cell floor. Mary scrambles in her chains to retrieve it. Aiken looks down Mary with a cold detachment.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Perhaps, to save your daughter, you'd consider telling me the truth. Mary turns, looks up beseechingly at Aiken.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What's happened to Anna? Aiken LIES to her.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: She's disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Where to?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I have no idea. I suspect they intend to hang her alongside of you.

dialogues.speaker: MARY,
dialogues.text: You're cruel, Colonel Aiken.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: If you want to help her, ma'am, you better start telling me the truth.  45.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'll tell you anything to protect my daughter. Even if it means confessing to something I did not do.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Guard. Aiken raps on the cell door

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm not defending your lies any longer. And I damn well am not making enemies on account of you. Aiken begins to exit.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You say you want the truth, Mr. Aiken. But you're so blind with vengeance, you can't see it anymore.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Try me.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: My son abhorred the North. We all did! How can a Southerner not feel anything but bitterness towards your side for denying us our independence? But, my son did not conspire to kill your President. A beat. Aiken turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He conspired to kidnap him. Aiken STOPS DEAD in his tracks.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: KIDNAP Lincoln?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: ...A SLENDER MAN, 21, with wispy goatee atop a horse.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: It is JOHN SURRATT, and he's concealed in the bushes alon remote road. SIX more HORSEMEN are hidden on either side. All but John Surratt are familiar from the trial -- ATZER ARNOLD, HEROLD, O'LAUGHLIN, PAYNE and BOOTH. A FANCY CARRIAGE approaches from around the bend. The kidnappers await Booth's signal to strike. Suddenly, Surratt's HORSE bucks prematurely. The COACHMAN spots him, then the others. He strikes his whip, plunging his Carriage forward. Booth SIGNALS to pur  46. The Carriage races ahead. Booth and Payne cut through the WOODS. The Coachman takes it too fast around a curve, cau his Carriage to pitch momentarily onto two wheels. Booth and Payne intercept the Carriage, their RIFLES draw Surratt is the last to pull up alongside. Everything is already well under control. The Coachman is unlocking the Carriage door. But Surratt is overeager and pokes him with his GUN.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN SURRATT
dialogues.text: We got ourselves Abe. He exclaims as the Carriage door is pulled open, revealin TwO MIDDLE-AGED LADIES -- corpulent and panic-stricken. Booth looks DAGGERS at Surratt. EXT./INT. SURRATT BOARDINGHOUSE -- LATER (FLASHBACK CONT. The failed KIDNAPPERS ride up to the front stoop, as seen from Mary's POV out the parlor window. As John Surratt le the others INSIDE, Mary retreats to the back of the house where Anna is cleaning.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Anna, upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Mother.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Now. Anna heads upstairs. Mary remains. She can barely make ou what is being said down the hall. SAMUEL ARNOLD, 31, is barking at DAVID HEROLD, 23.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL ARNOLD
dialogues.text: The war is lost now 'cause of you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID HEROLD
dialogues.text: I was told he'd be there.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN SURRATT
dialogues.text: He's right. I heard the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL O'LAUGHLIN
dialogues.text: (to Surratt) You couldn't even control your mount.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS PAYNE
dialogues.text: Fools like you two are the reason we're losing this fight. Payne pushes Surratt. O'Laughlin squares off with Herold. Booth raises his PISTOL. He points the barrel at Herold.

dialogues.speaker: BOOTH
dialogues.text: Enough!  47.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID HEROLD
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. It won't happen again. Then he aims it at Surratt. Holds it there.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN SURRATT
dialogues.text: Wilkes, what are you doing? Booth fingers the trigger. Mary calls out. MARY (0.S. Johnnie Surratt, I'd like a word with you. Booth lowers his gun.

dialogues.speaker: BOOTH
dialogues.text: Answer, Johnnie. Your mommy's calling. Off the others laughing at the young man, we CUT BACK TO

dialogues.speaker: PRESENT TIME
dialogues.text: Aiken is rapt as Mary reveals the details of the plot.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Seemed they planned on ransoming him in_exchange for all the Confederate soldiers kept inside your prisons.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Why didn't you report them to the authorities?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: "Cause one of 'them' was my son.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Instead of kidnapping the President your son helped murder him -- and he nearly got the Vice President and Secretary of State as well.

dialogues.speaker: MARY _
dialogues.text: No. Not my Johnnie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn it, ma'am. You just said so yourself.

dialogues.speaker: _ MARY
dialogues.text: No, my son is not a murderer. Aiken thrusts Mary's BIBLE at her.

dialogues.speaker: _ AIKEN
dialogues.text: Swear to it. Mary's agony is evident... As we CUT TO --  48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOWNSTAIRS, Anna cooks a meal for many. UPSTAIRS, Mary en her son's bedroom to find John busy packing.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Wash up, Johnnie. Supper will be ready shortly.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN SURRATT
dialogues.text: I can't stay, mama. I have to leave town straightaway.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What could be more pressing than fried chicken?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN SURRATT
dialogues.text: Nothing that need worry you. Just some cotton speculating, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Don't sport with me, son! You're not stepping outside this house.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN SURRATT
dialogues.text: Don't speak to me like I'm a child.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You and Anna are all the family I've got left. I'll be damned if I let you run off and do something else oolish.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: "Foolish!" What I'm fighting for is far more important than any of us.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Sweetheart, nine tenths of our army is buried underground. You think they'll wait until we grow another? The war is all but over, love. There is nothing more you can do.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: The war is far from over, mother There's still much we can do! John turns to leave. Mary grabs hold.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: John, please.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Unhand me, mother. But Mary won't let go. John pushes Mary as he tries to br free. She stumbles, banging her face on the table -- cutt her eyebrow. Blood begins to trickle down her face.  49.

dialogues.speaker: BOOTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (shouts from downstairs) John, are you coming or not?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN SURRATT
dialogues.text: For God's sake, mother, if this cause ain't worth dying for, what is? He turns and exits. Off Mary's dismay we CUT BACK TO --

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And this happened when?

dialogues.speaker: PRESENT TIME
dialogues.text: A SCAR, now healed, is above Mary's RIGHT EYE.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: April 3rd.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Eleven days prior to the assassination? Mary nods. Tears are streaking her face.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So then you admit your son did conspire to murder President Lincoln?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: May God help you. Aiken turns for the door

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Honestly, I don't. Lord, I pray not. I only know that I did not. (a beat) I swear. Mary's hand is on the Bible. Off Aiken and Mary in silenc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Aiken exits the front gate. He stops and turns back toward the prison -- with a look stunned disbelief. And then continues on his way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aiken purposefully ascends the front stoop. He salutes th new SOLDIER posted out front, and enters without knocking
Aiken beelines for Anna, who is sweeping up shattered gla

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: You knew about the train ticket, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: And good evening to you, Colonel. Did you see my mother?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: She's fine.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You told her not to worry about me? Again, Aiken lies.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Yes, I told her. Why didn't you just give me the ticket? Instead of oping I'd find it. Anna ascends a ladder to fix a broken window.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Because you never would've offered it in Court.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Chain of Custody: the ability to guarantee evidence from collection to presentation in Court. Off Aiken's surprised look, Anna explains --

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Counselor, a boardinghouse with no guests leaves one with plenty of spare time. Then nods to a stack of law journals nearby.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Then you're aware I can't possibly defend your mother unless I know what's coming next.

dialogues.speaker: / ANNA
dialogues.text: Meaning?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I believe you know what witnesses the prosecution may call, and the evidence they'll use against her.  51.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Wonderful, Mr. Aiken. Now, you're accusing me of "building the. nest". At least you're introducing reasonable doubt for my mother. Smash! Anna whacks a broken pane from the window.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Do you need some help?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I can manage.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Please let me do it.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Thanks just the same. But my father and brother's example taught me never to depend on a man. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: How dong . did you know Lt. Wiechmann was working for the Confederacy?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: A while. And he didn't work hard enough.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Lou was too much of a coward to devote himself to the Cause. That's why I'd never consider marrying him.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: He proposed to you?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Don't seem so surprised by the notion Mr. Aiken. Fact is, I was in love with a man -- not_a boy. Lt. Wiechmann didn't like that.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
