dialogues.text: You really think that's why he testified against your mothe

dialogues.speaker: . ANNA
dialogues.text: For it is written, vengeance is mine.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Any other Louis Wiechmanns I need to be prepared for? Anna, atop the ladder, turns and catches Aiken's eye wand up the back of her skirt.  52.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Are you more interested in me or defending my mother, Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I'm interested in the truth. Starting with: where's your brother?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I don't have the slightest idea.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Then perhaps you'll level with me about what I can expect next at trial. Several beats ensue.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're going to have to learn to "depend" on me, Miss Surratt. Anna thinks on it. Finally, she descends the ladder. She gestures Aiken into the PARLOR -- the exact spot where Booth and the others m As Anna and Aiken begin to go over the case, we CUT TO --

dialogues.speaker: HOLT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ...Let us_ proceed with events immediately following the assassination of President Lincoln.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: MAJOR H.W. SMITH, precise in manner and response, fills t WITNESS BOX. (The Major was seen earlier reporting to Sta immediately after the assassination.) The prosecutor, HOL is beside him, as the case against Mary Surratt continues

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Major Smith, what were your duties that night?

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR SMITH
dialogues.text: I was charged with finding John Surratt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DOZEN POLICEMEN ransack the house, fii pping over furni paintings and rugs. A PATROLMAN approaches Major Smith.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: No sign of the son. PATROLMAN #2 comes down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: Major, take a look. He hands the Major a stack of card-sized PICTURES.  53.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: We found these upstairs in the daughter's bedroom. Pointing at Anna Surratt, still in her nightshirt. Louis Wiechmann is nearby, looking fearful. INSERT: Each IMAGE as the Major flips through them: -- First, a half-dozen DAGUERREOTYPES of CONFEDERATE GENE including pictures of Generals Lee, Beauregard and Jackso -- Then, a PRINTED CARD featuring the seal of the state o Virginia with Confederate flags. -- And lastly, a color LITHOGRAPH of a nursery fable, tit "Morning, Noon & Night". The Major examines the fable more closely. He flips it ov revealing a PHOTO on the reverse side of JOHN WILKES BOOT

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR SMITH
dialogues.text: Young lady, does this belong to you? Mary shields her daughter

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: This young lady belongs to me!

dialogues.speaker: PRESENT TIME
dialogues.text: Holt holds up the CARD baring the Virginia state seal.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Major. Please read aloud what's inscribed here. The Major positions his reading glasses.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR SMITH
dialogues.text: Sic semper tyrannis.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Can you translate?

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR SMITH
dialogues.text: Of course. "Thus always for tyrants."

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Are these words familiar to you?

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR SMITH
dialogues.text: Indeed. Booth yelled them after he butchered our President.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: And you found the same -- just an hour later -- in her daughter's bedroom next to a photo of the assassin himself?  54.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR SMITH
dialogues.text: Like a shrine, sir.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: That's preposterous. Sic semper tyrannis is the state motto of Virginia. This is hardly proof of a shrine to Booth. General Hunter interjects with contempt.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: No more proof is needed, Colonel. Aiken is stunned silent.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Major Smith, please tell us what happened next.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR SMITH
dialogues.text: As I was fixin' to take the Surratts down to headquarters for questioning, I heard a commotion outside... ...The sound of several men SHOUTING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major Smith draws his gun before opening the back door Lewis Payne (Booth's TALL ASSOCIATE, who attacked the Secretary of State) is standing in the doorway. Payne is sweating profusely -- like the fugitive he is -- with PICKAXE in hand. He is surrounded by TWO SOLDIERS.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: We found him sneaking around outside.

dialogues.speaker: PAYNE
dialogues.text: I told these imbeciles a lady inside asked me to dig a gutter for her.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR SMITH
dialogues.text: At this time of night?

dialogues.speaker: PAYNE
dialogues.text: In the morning. I just wanted to know what time I should start. Major Smith turns to Anna, who is watching from the doorw

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR SMITH
dialogues.text: Is this true? Anna says nothing. Major Smith calls into the PARLOR.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR SMITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mrs. Surratt. Come here a moment. Major Smith spots BLOODSTAINS on the back of Payne's slee He takes the pickaxe from his hand.  55.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR SMITH
dialogues.text: Did you hire this gentleman to do a job for you?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Absolutely not. I've never seen him before in all my life.

dialogues.speaker: PRESENT TIME
dialogues.text: Holt stands beside Lewis Payne at the prisoners' dock

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Is this man, Lewis Payne, the one she denied knowing?

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR SMITH
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: The same man, who has confessed to boarding at the Surratt's several times -- prior to daggerin' the Secretary of State and his kin.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR SMITH
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Thank you, Major. Nothing further Holt sits down triumphantly. Aiken rises.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Are you aware Mr. Payne boarded at the Surratt's under an alias, claiming to be a Baptist minister from Baltimore named Wood?

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR SMITH
dialogues.text: That's what she claimed.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Supposing it was the truth. Supposing Mrs. Surratt simply failed that night to recognize Wood, the preacher, in the guise of Payne, the ditch digger.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR SMITH
dialogues.text: Not possible. He stood barely two paces in front of her. Aiken pulls a LETTER from his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Your honor, I present the court with a notarized letter from Dr. Sanford Wilkerson, a well respected optometrist in town. Aiken presents the letter to General Hunter.  56.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mary Surratt has been a patient under his care for the past six years, suffering from severe presbyopia -- more commonly known as farsightedness. General Hunter examines the letter. But not before having to put on a pair of READING GLASSES himself.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Major Smith, it was late at night. The defendant was dressed for sleep. Isn't it possible she merely had trouble seeing him?

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR SMITH
dialogues.text: Well, I uh..

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: A simple yes or no.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR SMITH
dialogues.text: Yes, it's possible...I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: So, it's also possible you -- or rather we -- might also be wrongfully accusing her of disloyalty too? Major Smith holds up the daguerreotypes.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR SMITH
dialogues.text: I_think these more than indicate her allegiances, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Have you not seen the like in stores around town?

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR SMITH
dialogues.text: Yes, of course, but...

dialogues.speaker: _ AIKEN
dialogues.text: So, do you intend to arrest me too? Aiken presents to the Court an identical set.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's next? Roun ing up everyone whose name rhymes with General Lee? Several laugh aloud, including Baker and Catherine.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR SMITH
dialogues.text: Course not.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Then I dare say, we ought to presume the accused is innocent unless we have proof beyond a reasonable doubt. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (a beat) A thirst for vengeance, Major, is not enough to avenge this crime. Even Hamilton has to admire Aiken's commanding presence..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverdy Johnson is eating his supper ALONE. The doorbell rings. A STEWARD goes to answer the door. Reverdy calls out.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: I'll take the transcript in here. MAN'S VOICE (0.S. Sure you don't want me to read it aloud? Reverdy instantly recognizes the voice, looks up. It's STANTON. He hands Reverdy the transcript.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: You're associate is putting up quite a spirited defense. Reminds me of a lawyer I faced 35 years ago.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: He learned to fight in your army.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Our young men certainly have been through four years of hell.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: And we older ones better ensure it was worth the fight.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Reverdy, you've done as much for our nation as anyone I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feeling's mutual, Ed.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Don't you think it's time us war horses called a truce?

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Not if you insist on staging this abomination.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: What you consider an 'abomination' will do more to keep the peace than any paper treaty could.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: How'd you convince yourself of that?  58.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Because it will deter the South from conspiring again. And discourage the North from seeking revenge.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: What about the rule of law?

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: For God's sake, we've never known an enemy like this. They enjoy our freedom at the same time they plot to destroy us. Your actions only serve to aid them -- by eroding our unity and diminishing our resolve.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: By abandoning our laws we become just like them. Stanton begins to leave.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: You may prefer eating alone, Senator But do you really want the Colonel doing so the rest of his life? qa beat) If_he continues this way this case will destroy him. You know I'm right about this. Off Reverdy Johnson taking this in...

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So, this one time we were surrounded by a rebel column.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: Aiken is seated at an elegant DINING TABLE surrounded by friends -- notably Baker and Hamilton. Catherine is acros from Aiken. Baker is mid-story.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Their General yells out, "I demand you surrender immediately !" Well, Freddie shouts back, "my compliments, General. But we don't Surrender!" All eyes are once again on Aiken.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "Hope you said your prayers," the General replies. "Cause they're 400 of us. And only 100 of you!" Aiken pretends not to revel in the attention.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "Heck, we've got less than that," Freddie hollers back (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BAKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "But we don't surrender. So, shut up and come get some." And with that, Freddie pulls down his pants and bares his ass.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE GUEST
dialogues.text: No, he didn't.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: As the moon is my witness. Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE GUEST
dialogues.text: So, did they come? Hamilton jealously glares at his date.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Six times. And each time the General shouts out, "I won't ask you again. Now, surrender at once." (a beat "Pray don't," Freddie shouts back. "For we never surrender!" And then he blows a tremendous fart in their direction.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE GUEST
dialogues.text: He didn't! ; BAKER ; His seventh was so deadly it sent them runnin' for their lives! The TABLE erupts in laughter.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Doesn't seem like the Colonel ever intends to surrender.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Only for the right woman. Baker smiles reassuringly at Catherine.

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: Appears the Colonel has surrendered to one -- she's fair, fit and 45.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I don't see why the Lieutenant insists on bringing his mother into this. More laughter. Hamilton seethes. Baker attempts to pacify

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Freddie, why don't you tell _us what your conspirator is really like. I'm sure we'd all like to know.  60.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE GUEST
dialogues.text: fcontemptuously) I understand she's a Catholic.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE GUEST
dialogues.text: Is it true she wears black from head- to-toe as if she's in mourning?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Perhaps, by papal decree.

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: How did you do it, Fred?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: How did I do what?

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: Destroy that Major on cross like that? The doctor's letter, the postcards... You didn't bluff your way through this one. As Baker raises his artificial leg --

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: My leg's falling asleep. Let's go dance.

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: You knew what was coming, didn't you, Fred? Those meetings with the Surratt girl seem to be paying off. An awkward silence. Baker glances at Catherine.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Are you through, Bill? (Hamilton says nothing) Good. Now, let's dance. Baker rises. The others follow suit. We HOLD ON Aiken and Catherine -- still seated... ...Gradually, PIANO MUSIC begins to fill the room.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: As Baker is now at a piano, playing/singing, "The Childre of the Battle Field". He has a sonorous voice. But only Aiken is around to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Upon the Field of Gettysburg The full moon slowly rose, She looked, and saw 10,000 brows All pale in death's repose... Baker continues singing as Aiken is deep in thought and w Catherine enters the room.  61.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: If I had known it was a wake, I'd have dressed more appropriately. Aiken turns to take in Catherine's floral dress.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: You're the vision of perfection, Catherine.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: You lie, pass gas and never surrender Quite a catch. a_beat) Why defend her, Freddie?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Not you too, Catherine.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Is it because of Senator Johnson? I know your father and he were very close. But you don't owe it to either of them.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Does it have to do with Anna Surratt? Aiken is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Bill is an ass.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: I understand she's very beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Catherine, please.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: I accepted not hearing from you for 18 months. The front must've been horrible. But I will not accept our silence on why you're defending er.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I don't know. (off her skepticism) Honestly, Catherine. I don't. Catherine can see Aiken means it. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Just one more thing.  62.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: You're the one who doesn't "surrender". What? What do you need to know?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Does the Colonel still remember how to dance? They exchange looks. He holds out his hand. She takes it. Baker starts to pray a slow waltz on the piano. With each turn across the floo the distance between Aiken and Catherine becomes less. Aiken inhales Catherine's scent as she grasps his shoulde His eyes begin to fall to half-staff. His head rests agai hers. It looks as if Aiken is finally going to surrender. Suddenly, he pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: There's something I need to ask you.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Of course, Freddie. You can ask me anything? Off Catherine waiting expectantly...

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I want you to wear this in court today.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: As Aiken presents Mary with Catherine's floral DRESS. Mar doesn't take it.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I want the truth from you this time. Aiken knows exactly what she's after.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Anna never went missing.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: She's been helping you all along? Aiken nods.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How could you lie to me about such a thing?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I needed to know the truth about your son.  63.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Nothing they do to me could compare to the torture of not knowing my daughter was ok.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Aiken pulls out NEWSPAPER CLIPPINGS from his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Please leave. AIKEN (CONT'D. (reads from a clipping "Mrs. Surratt looks no less masculine than the male prisoners on trial -- removing any doubt a woman like her could be capable of such a crime." (re. other clippings) The others are less kin Aiken holds out the dress. Mary refuses it.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It matters none to me what they think.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: It matters to me. This country has never executed a woman. We need those Generals to begin seeing their own wives in you. Mary grimaces momentarily, but conceals it from Aiken.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You speak of womanhood with such reverence, Mr. Aiken. Yet, we aren't trusted enough to vote, while a former slave now can as long as he has $250. (heavy Southern drawl) Yes, I'm certain y'all would prefer I acted like a good Southern lady. Met my fate in that pretty dress with a painted face. But, I'd prefer to act naturally . And take the consequences like a man.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Please. Ma'am. Wear the dress, smile at those Generals and pray they show you some mercy. Mary holds a beat. She starts undressing in front of Aike

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Just obeying orders, Colonel.  64. She drops her black dress to the floor. Starts unlacing h corset. She is now standing in a calf-length chemise. She slips off her pantalettes, and tosses it into the bucket.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come now, Freddie, don't be shy. Surely, you've undressed a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're insane. Mary presses up against Aiken, seductively.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'm just showing you how I'd please those Generals.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Stop it! Aiken pushes Mary to the ground, just as her son did at t boardinghouse. But this time Mary doesn't get up.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ma'am? (no response) Ma'am. Are you alright? Aiken spots her chemise in the bucket, stained BLOOD RED. Aiken calls out.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Call a doctor. Mary remains crumpled, clutching her belly.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Call a doctor. NOw! ..A door marked: SECRETARY of WAR

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: An AIDE intercepts Aiken outside Secretary Stanton's door

dialogues.speaker: STANTON'S AIDE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir. No one sees Mr. Stanton without an appointment. Joseph Holt emerges from inside. HOLT. Good morning, Colonel. Perhaps I can be of assistance.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Fyou can arrange a meeting for me wat the Secretary. My client is not well  65.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: So I heard. Just a touch of the woman's curse, thank goodness. She'll be well enough to continue with her trial within a few days. In the meantime, we'll pursue our case against the other Conspirators.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: My client requires a proper meal and some fresh air. Otherwise, I can not assure you she'll be fit for trial. Which is why I must see the Secretary -- immediately.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, he's quite busy right now. Perhaps, you'd take a turn with me instead. Aiken hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please, Colonel. Aiken reluctantly follows Holt outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Aiken and Holt continue their conversation across swam Pennsylvania Avenue. The WHITE HOUSE looms in the backgro HOLT. One of the Conspirators refuses to be guarded by a Negro. Another will only eat his mother's cooking. We can't accommodate every whim.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I'm merely asking you stop treating her like a savage.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: How dare you accuse US of savagery? An AMPUTEE crosses in front of Holt and Aiken's path.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you forgotten how our own were treated by the rebels? Thousands starved to death at Andersonville. Not to mention the horrors for those held at Libby and Liggett's Farm.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: It hardly enhances our cause to act as the enemy would.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Security demands it.  66.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Mary Surratt is not a present danger I assure you.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Can you say the same about her daughter?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Anna Surratt? Of course. But I'm sure you've been tracking her every move.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Not well enough. She disappeared last night.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: What? Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: I thought you might know.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Then I can only conclude she does not wish to be found -- much like her brother. Both men pass inside the prestigious CENTURY CLUB.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Aiken and Holt continue up the Club's GRAND STAIRCASE.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: ...Counselor, I appreciate your zeal in defending your client. But I hardly think it prudent to do so at your own peril.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: "Peril"?

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: You exhibit a bright future, dear boy. Don't dim it by mounting unnecessary campaigns.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: You offer me no other alternative. Holt freezes, makes certain NO ONE else is listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I know a way to save both your client -- and yourself. A beat.  67.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll deny ever telling you this. Understood? Off Aiken nodding...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful late Spring day. Aiken spots Mary across the open-air courtyard. She has made a swift recovery -- exercising in the sunlight, her arms now free of chains. She is wearing the dress given t her by Aiken, the plunging neckline tempered by a shawl. Father Walter passes Aiken, after having prayed with Mary

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Good Morning, Father.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER WALTER
dialogues.text: Colonel. Aiken approaches Mary tentatively.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You should've pushed me down a month ago, if that's what it took to spell me from that cage. Feel that sun. Now, all I need is a few boiled oysters with Spanish olives. (giddy ) . Your mama ever boil oysters for you Frederick? Aiken is taken aback by Mary's use of his first name.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: No, ma'am. I never had the good fortune to taste my mother's cooking.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: She doesn't cook?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: She passed when I was born.

dialogues.speaker: MARY,
dialogues.text: I feel for your loss -- and hers. (a beat Some day I'll make oysters for you -- with Spanish olives, of course. You must never eat 'em without the olives.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I look forward to it. Aiken struggles for the right words.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mary. I, uh...  68.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Young man, I don't believe I've seen you ata loss for words. Aiken comes right out with it.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Do you know where your son is hiding?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (laughs) My Johnnie! 'Course not!

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: The government believes you do. That you're in contact.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: From here?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Ma'am, you need to tell us where he is.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: "US!" Whose side are you on?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I'm trying to save your life.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: By suggesting I trade my son's life for my own. Seems more like you're trying to save yourself.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: How dare you! You think I asked to defend you?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: "Course not. But every time you walk out those gates something pulls ou back inside. Well, if you're ooking to slip out the back door yout have to unlock it yourself. ecause I have no idea where my son is hiding.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: How about your daughter?

dialogues.speaker: MARY,
dialogues.text: You've already played that card, Mr. Aiken. Now, if you please, I wish to enjoy the rest of this glorious gay. There may not be many more eft. Mary resumes her exercises.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Are you absolutely certain?  69.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: As Aiken now confers with Reverdy Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: The Secretary assures me they don't have her.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Anna chose to flee? Why would she do that?

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Perhaps she's as guilty as her brother.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Do you believe that?

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: It matters none. Fact is with two children abandoning Mrs. Surratt, it'll only be seen one way -- their mother must be guilty.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I think Mary may be innocent.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Is that so? Well, "Mary" and "Anna" they're my concern now. Your wish is granted, Fred. I'm taking you off the case. Reverdy rises, heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aiken chases after Reverdy.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: But you said I had to prove her guilty.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: You haven't proven she's not.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: So, you don't think I'm up to the task of defending her?

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Quite the contrary. I just think it's best for all concerned that I take over from here.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: But_your presence in that courtroom will antagonize those generals. You said so yourself.  70.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: I can manage. But Aiken soon realizes Reverdy isn't only referring to t case as he's just followed his boss inside the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Embarrassed, Aiken quickly exits. Reverdy closes the door

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (calls out) Few will soon forget on whose side you Fought here, Fred. Trust me it's a lonely place to be.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: (calls back) Sir, a man must be willing to walk on faith alone. You said so yourself.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: This habit of quoting me back to me is most irritating. Flush. Reverdy reemerges from the water closet.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You've got your mother's conviction. And your father's annoying habits. Reverdy returns to his office with Aiken in tow...

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: With all due respect, I never knew my mother. And my father only through al his books. So, the only bad bits I picked up are from you -- sir. (a beat) Mary Surratt is entitled to a defense. So, I shall defend her. Reverdy thinks on it.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Are you sure you want this?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Unfortunately. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Very well, Fred. (another beat) So, tell me, how do you intend to convince the Generals she's innocent after they hear she was carrying a package from Booth -- just hours efore he murdered Lincoln?  71.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: According to her daughter, she was merely returning a favor to Booth.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Dr. Mudd did Booth a favor by fixin' his broken leg. Now, he's facing life in prison. Edward Spangler held Booth's horse outside Ford's Theater and is looking at hard labor So, don't do your client any "favors" by offering that as a defense.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: What do you suggest I do?

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: If it's John Surratt they want, then present him to those Generals on a platter. It's the only chance she's got.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: How? I haven't a clue where he is. And if all the resources of the Government can't find him, I hardly think I will by hour's end.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: I don't mean in oth -- in spirit. You must prove to them her son is responsible -- not her.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Mary won't like it. She insists on leaving him out of it.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Better to hate you alive, than love you from the grave. A long beat as we CUT TO -- FULL SCREEN: on an ARTIST's SKETCH of the next WITNESS.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: As_we reveal the SKETCH is being drawn by a member of the Military Commission -- GENERAL LEWIS WALLACE. (Note: Gene Wallace is perpetually sketching throughout the trial.)

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Mr. Lloyd, you are employed by Mary Surratt, are you not? JOHN LLOYD, 54, rotund and ruddy-cheeked, wears a Panama hat, white suit and as many folds on the back of his red neck as around his waist.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. I run a tavern started by her late husband many years ago.  72. Aiken looks over at Mary. She looks away.

dialogues.speaker: HO
dialogues.text: On the afternoon President Lincoln was assassinated, did Mrs. Surratt pay you a visit?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Indeed. In the company of Lt. Louis Wiechmann.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and Wiechmann ride atop a BUGGY along a COUNTRY ROAD A wooden TAVERN sits atop a rolling plain. Wiechmann guid the buggy up to the PORCH as Lloyd rushes out to greet th

dialogues.speaker: PRESENT TIME
dialogues.text: Holt continues his line of questioning.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Mrs. Surratt gave you a package, did she not?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. C'rect, sir. A small package, wrapped in newspaper...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mary hands the WRAPPED PACKAGE to Lloyd on his back po

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Did she tell you where the package came from?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: She told me it came from John Wilkes Booth. The Gallery begins to stir.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: From 'Booth!' And what exactly did she give you?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Objection!

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Objection?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Yes. There's no proof the defendant knew herself. He just testified the package was wrapped.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: She damn well handed it to him.  73.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Mr. Booth was friends with John Surratt -- not the defendant. Mary glares at Aiken.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: Objection overruled. The witness will answer the question.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Mr. Lloyd, what was inside?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Field glasses, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Are these the ones? Holt holds up a pair of BINOCULARS. Lloyd inspects them.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: 'Xactly.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Did she give you any instructions?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Instructions, Mr. Lloyd. Instructions which might affect this trial? The QUESTION puzzles both Aiken and Mary. Lloyd reacts to "instruction" as though it were a CODE.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Oh, yes...yes, sir. (as if memorized) She told me: "Lloyd, get those shooting irons ready. There'll be par ties here tonight who'll call for them."

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You liar! Mary screams out. General Hunter slams his gavel.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: Control yourself, ma'am. Such outbursts will only prejudice your case. Mary guffaws.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You find that amusing?  74.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I just don't see how I could possibly further prejudice this case.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: Counselor, control your client! Aiken turns to Mary. But he, too, can barely contain his own amusement at Mary's quip. They share a quick smile.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: "Shooting irons!' To what was she referring?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Army rifles, sir. Hidden in the joists above my storeroom.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: By whom?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: By her son, John. Six weeks earlier Lloyd glares over at Mary.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: And were these weapons called for as per the defendant's instructions?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Around midnight, sir, the night of the assassination. By two men on horses. One of â€˜em I'd seen before... Lloyd points at DAVID HEROLD, 22, inside the prisoners' d Herold bows his head.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...The other kept his mount. He was a stranger to me, and seemed to have injured his leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Booth, with a broken ankle, remains atop his HORSE outsid Lloyd's tavern. His identity is concealed behind his coll Herold dismounts from his ride and follows Lloyd inside. LLOYD (V.O. I_fetched the rifles and field glasses, supposing they were the parties Mrs. Surratt had meant. Herold returns moments later with the SUPPLIES in hand.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The two of â€˜em rode off so fast, they could've outrun creation and give it two mile the start.  75. Booth and Herold race into the night.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT.
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Lloyd. Thank_you very much. Your witness, Colonel. Holt returns to his seat, a smug grin on his face.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Mr. Lloyd, you just testified Lt. Wiechmann accompanied the defendant that afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: So then I can correctly assume he'd also testify to having heard Mrs. Surratt's instructions to you?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: "No"? But they were seated side by side.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: She took me out by the wood pile and told me out of earshot. _ AIKEN ; You're saying no one else heard this conversation? Just you and her?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: That's just the way it happened. Sir.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Of course it is. Aiken and Holt exchange glances.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When did you first learn the President had been assassinated, Mr. Lloyd?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: No one will ever forget the moment they heard. I was told early the next morning by a Captain Cottingham, who was searching for the assassins.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: No doubt, you were most upset!  76.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Indeed. I got myself right smart in liquor the remainder of the day.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: In fact, you're right smart most days. Aren't you, mate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I enjoy a round or two.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: You shared a few with the defendant's late husband, isn't that right?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Every now and again.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: You were fond of him, weren't you?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: He was always good for a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: And for overlooking a debt.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: We had an understanding.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Which you and the defendant don't. In fact, the day she and Mr. Wiechmann visited the tavern, Mrs. Surratt inquired about a significant sum you owed her late husband. Isn't that correct?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Yeah, so?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: So, you have a financial stake in the outcome of this trial.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: If you're suggesting I aim to profit from our President's death, I've got a good mind to put you in the ground.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Your words, Mr. Lloyd, not mine. Lloyd stands up as if he's going to attack Aiken.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Objection! This courageous witness is a former policeman. He deserves our gratitude, not unfounded accusations.  77.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: Sustained. Mr. Aiken, show the witness some respect.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Yes, General. Thank you, Mr. Lloyd. We're all so indebted to you. (a beat) May I continue, your honor? General Hunter nods.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: Please be seated, Mr. Lloyd. Lloyd does as told. Reverdy enters the back of the courtr

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Mr. Lloyd, when this Captain Cottingham visited you after the assasSination, did he ask anything in reference to the assassins?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: He asked if any parties had passed through. Naturally, I told them about the two I knew. Aiken withdraws a document from his files.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: According to this witness report, you didn't actually inform him until wo days later.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I was frightened is all.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Perhaps, you feared you might be considered an accessory.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I told him it was through the Surratts that I'd gotten myself in such a difficulty.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: John Surratt to be more precise. After all, he's the one who concealed those "shooting irons" inside your tavern months earlier. Not you.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Perhaps, he threatened to foreclose on your tavern if you refused. Lloyd looks confused. Mary leans forward in her chair  78.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Were those John Surratt's "instructions" to you?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: (getting Aiken's ist) Yes, exactly. He said he'd take it away from me if I didn't do what he said.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Objection. There's no evidence John Surratt did anything of the sort. And since Mr. Surratt's whereabouts are unknown at this time --

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: -- As the General said, Mr. Surratt's absence from this proceeding is Mr. Surratt's problem. By quoting Hunter's own words, he's forced his hand --

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: Objection overruled.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: So, if John Surratt could implicate a dear friend of his father's, like yourself, who's to say he didn't do the same to his own mother as well. Mary lunges at the rail.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Stop this. Stop this right now.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Objection.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Or that the only crime Mary Surratt may be guilty of is having given birth to her son, John.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: How dare you! You have no right. General Hunter bangs his gavel repeatedly.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Objection, your honor. This is an outrage.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: Objection sustained. Mr. Aiken, I'm warning you.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: But sir --  79.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: That will be all, counselor One of the MEMBERS of the COMMISSION points to his WATCH. General Hunter takes it as a CUE and abruptly changes cou

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: S you know, tonight marks Was ington's celebration honoring our soldiers. We shall adjourn now to prepare our faces for this evening's festivities. Mr. Lloyd, you may step down. Lloyd exits the WITNESS BOX, very satisfied with himself. Aiken says to Lloyd under his breath --

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: So, what did they promise you? an HOLT Objection, your honor!

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER AIKEN
dialogues.text: Counselor, control Bet a case of whiskey is yourself. all it took. Aiken and Lloyd begin to square off as if to fight.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: Control yourself. Or I will hold you in contempt. A BAILIFF steps between Aiken and Lloyd, quickly escortin the latter outside. General Hunter slams his gavel.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll reconvene promptly at 09:00. (to Aiken) And when we do, young man, you'd better comport yourself in a more appropriate manner. Or else you'll find yourself in the brig alongside the others. Hunter slams his gavel. Holt looks at Aiken as if to say: "you're playing with fire." Mary glares at him with conte Reverdy Johnson looks distressed for Aiken. There's no turning back now. . FIREWORKS explode into the NIGHT SKY.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: The NATION'S CAPITAL consumed in CELEBRATION, its MONUMEN bathed in light. We HOLD ON a BANNER that reads: The Century Club Honors

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: GUESTS pass beneath the banner on their way to the grand ballroom upstairs. WALTZ music filters down from above. The Century Club is filled with the POWERS-THAT-BE and PO TO-BE, mostly attired in their finest military dress. Aiken enters quite dapper in his dress whites. Eager for festive night-on-the-town. Catherine is on his arm. They pass the Club Steward, OTIS, on his way upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN/CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Good evening, Otis.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: Evenin', Colonel. Miss Morgan. Suddenly, Otis' expression changes from welcome to alarm.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just a minute, Colonel Aiken. Can I have a word? Otis ushers Aiken out of Catherine's earshot.

dialogues.speaker: OTIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They! re tellin' me I ain't allowed et you in there.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? As Catherine waits patiently, she spots a BULLETIN BOARD posted nearby.

dialogues.speaker: DEAR MEMBERS
dialogues.text: .Reverend Peale has agreed to. .Construction will begin on. Finally SETTLING on: .The membership of MR. FREDERICK AIKEN has been rescinded effective immediately as a result of conduct unbecoming The Century Club. E.M, Stanton Chairman, Board of Governors Suddenly, the sound of LAUGHTER -- Hamilton, with beauty tow, and Baker arriving. Aiken turns to Baker.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nick, would you please take Catherine inside for me.

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Is everything alright?  81.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Everything's fine. I'll join you as soon as I can. Go ahead, darling. Enjoy the evening. Gentleman. Aiken turns and heads for the door. Baker extends his arm

dialogues.speaker: BAKER
dialogues.text: Even on one I can outdance him.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: And one less foot for me to step on. Another night, Nick. Catherine kisses Baker on the cheek, and heads for the do

dialogues.speaker: OTIS
dialogues.text: Shall I call you a carriage, Miss Morgan?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Otis. Hamilton calls out.

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: Sure you don't want to join us Catherine? She turns and glares at Hamilton. And heads out the door without answering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catherine exits. Otis motions for a carriage to pull forw Aiken suddenly appears.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I've got it, Otis. Aiken helps Catherine into the CARRIAGE.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: I saw the announcement.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I'll take care of it in the morning. I'm sorry about this evening. Tears begin to fill her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry too. She slips off her engagement ring and returns it to Aiken The Carriage rides off. Aiken is now the outsider, and AL . A flash of LIGHTNING.  82.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: As BOLTS now light up the sky, replacing the fireworks. They illuminate Aiken, who waiks alone in a torrential RA A THUNDERCLAP echoes overhead. A UNION BAND marches past joyfully playing "Yankee Doodle" in the downpour. Aiken is forlorn and soaking wet. He spots a PUB ahead -- THE BLUE GOOSE & OYSTER BAR -- and quickly ducks inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aiken enters the pub, which is filled with a much ROUGHER CROWD than the upper crust at the Century Club gala. All eyes seem to follow him as he removes his drenched Un coat, and settles on a stool at the end of the bar.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Got none.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: How 'bout that bottle over there? Aiken points to a WHISKEY BOTTLE, three-quarters full.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: I don't want no trouble, Colonel. He gestures to the PATRONS, all fixed on Aiken. A BLOCK- HEAD leans in from Aiken's right, glaring at Aiken's unif

dialogues.speaker: BLOCK-HEAD
dialogues.text: (southern accent) Yanks ain't welcome here. Several MORE TOUGHS now circle behind. There's no mistaki now this is a Rebel bar. Nervously, Aiken rises to leave. A BARREL-CHEST blocks hi

dialogues.speaker: BARREL
dialogues.text: You're the one defending that Surratt women, aren't you? Aiken nods as he prepares for the worst.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Why didn't you say so? Suddenly, the entire pub descends upon Aiken. But instead of attacking him, they're hailing Aiken like a hero. HOLD ON: Aiken's expression registering his DISMAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aiken stumbles home dripping wet and drunk. He crosses inside his modest flat -- legal briefs, army mementoes and dirty clothes are strewn about. Framed DAGUERREOTYPES fill his mantel, including one of a young woman (Aiken's MOTHER). A closer look reveals she's inside a coffin, her death portrait. Another image is of young Aiken with his very formal-looking FATHER. A portra of PRESIDENT LINCOLN is the last photo shown. Aiken's windows are also broken like Anna's -- a ROCK pil is on the sill. One is inscribed: DIE REBEL DIE. Aiken begins removing his soggy clothes to prepare for sl suddenly, a HAND grabs his bare shoulder from behind. Aiken whirls, takes the attacker's feet out from under hi knocks him to the ground, and pins him...pins HER!

dialogues.speaker: FAMILIAR VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Frederick, stop. It's me. As we reveal ANNA SURRATT, with Aiken straddling her, one hand to her throat, another raised to strike.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: What the hell. Aiken, now suddenly sober, relaxes his grip.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: She's very beautiful. (Off Aiken's confusion) I saw you go in your club tonight. Aiken rolls off of Anna.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Anna. They think you're as guilty as your brother. Where have you been? A long beat. Then softly --

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You still want to know where he is? Another beat.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: You don't have to do this. No one should have to choose between their mother and their brother

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I found out how... Aiken cuts her off.  84. Please. I never should've put you in this position. I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Can you save my mother without him? (no reply) Can you, Fred? A long pause.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Probably not. Anna's eyes fill with tears. Aiken desperately wants to comfort her. She desperately wants to be comforted. Inste she hands him a NOTE and flees. Off Aiken's turmoil... ...A splash of WATER.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: As we reveal a BABY being BAPTIZED. Proud PARENTS and GRANDPARENTS surround a PRIEST performing the ritual bath Aiken watches the tender scene from a rear pew. The Priest, his identity still obscured, passes the Infan off to an ASSOCIATE, then exits through a side door Aiken follows behind.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm told you know the whereabouts of John Surratt.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: The Priest's identity is now revealed -- FATHER JACOB WAL (the Cleric twice shown visiting Mary in jaity) Aiken sho him the note on Anna's stationary with Walter's name on i

dialogues.speaker: FATHER WALTER
dialogues.text: You've been misinformed.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I need to see him right away.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER WALTER
dialogues.text: Not possible, Colonel. As I told Miss Surratt, I can only pass along a message. We believe it safer for everyone concerned.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: 'we'? Father Walter pinches his cleric's COLLAR.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER WALTER
dialogues.text: A few of us have chosen to provide him sanctuary.  85.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: You don't seem troubled by your choice.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER WALTER
dialogues.text: You prefer he, too, be crucified by this mob?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: "Crucified'! Aiken's loud exclamation brings one of Father Walter's ASSOCIATES to the CHAPEL DOOR. Aiken lowers his voice.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: John Surratt is hardly the 'Prince of Peace.' He's accused of murder and treason. Concealing him is not only immoral, Father, its illegal.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER WALTER
dialogues.text: (clutching a Bible) My laws are written here, counselor. My allegiance to God.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Forgive me, Father, but that's a bunch of cock-and-bull. The Bible bears just as many interpretations as does anything else. It does not give you the authority to decide right from wrong.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER WALTER
dialogues.text: You prefer Stanton having the power instead? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER WALTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I will pass along a_message, Colonel. But John Surratt, alone, Will choose whether or not to turn himself in. Off Father Walter...

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER, (0.S. -)
dialogues.text: Colonel Aiken, do you wish to call a witness in defense of the accused?

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: The courtroom is sweltering like an inferno. Many fan themselves with little relief.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Yes, your honor. I do. Will Miss Anna Surratt please step forward. Anna Surratt enters the courtroom.  86. As Anna is seated inside the WITNESS BOX, she gets her fi glimpse of her mother, nearly moving both to tears. Aiken, sensing Anna is coming apart, steps near. Just as he's about to say something --

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: resolute) I'm fine. As we CUT TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flock of GEESE fly over a secluded LOG CABIN, tucked in a dense WILDERNESS. A RIVER roars beside. A MAN in a dark suit wades across the river towards a YOU FISHERMAN casting for SALMON. A closer look reveals the suited man is a GRAY-HAIRED CLERIC. He bears an ENVELOPE, which he hands to the Young Fisherman. A closer look reveals the Young Fisherman is JOHN SURRATT as we CUT BACK TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aiken stands beside Anna at the witness box.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Miss Surratt, when is the last time you saw your brother, John?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Monday, the 3rd of April. Aiken turns to the Commission for emphasis.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Eleven days prior to the assasSination. Did he say where he was headed? She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: Please answer for the record.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: He did not. He only told me he had to leave town.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Miss Surratt, was your brother involved in a conspiracy to assassinate President Lincoln and other members of the Government? Anna looks at her mother, then looks away.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I can't say.  87.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: You can't? Or you won't?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I don't know if he was involved. I only know that my mother was not. Aiken glances at Wiechmann, seated in the gallery. Anna nods.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: According to Lt. Wiechmann, your mother "welcomed" these prisoners into her boardinghouse with open arms.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: It's not true. He's lying. (turns to wiechmann) How could you? She would sit up and wait for you at night, the same as for my own brother.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Objection.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: Miss Surratt. You will address this Commission, not the gallery. Is that understood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did your mother object to these men being at the boardinghouse?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: She said she did not_understand why strange persons should call there.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Then why didn't she refuse them?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: She Supposed their object was to see my brother.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: John Surratt?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: So_she_was merely treating them politely as any lady would?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yes.  88.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: What about John Wilkes Booth? Did she object to him as well?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Mr. Booth was not a stranger.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: In fact, he was friends with your brother, John. Was he not? Mary calls out to Aiken.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: That is enough. Anna glances at her mother.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Please answer the question, Miss Surratt. Anna proceeds, tentatively.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I never asked my brother what his friendship was to Booth.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: But the fact remains, Mr. Booth frequently called on your brother.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yes. Aiken presents a piece of evidence already presented in c the picture called "Morning, Noon and Night"

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Does this belong to you?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: It was given to me by that man Wiechmann.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: But it was you who put the photo of John Wilkes Booth behind it?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yes. I went to a daguerrean gallery one day to get a picture taken. I saw some photographs of Mr. Booth there, and being acquainted with him, I bought one, and took it home.

dialogues.speaker: IKEN
dialogues.text: Your brother must've been pleased you thought so highly of his friend.  89.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: When my brother saw it, he told me to tear it up and throw it in the fire. And that if I did not, he would take it from me.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Why? Why would your brother tell you to do that?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You'll have to ask him.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Miss Surratt. That will be all. Your witness. He turns to Holt.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: We have nothing, your honor. The People view Miss Surratt's situation with compassion. And can understand how she'd be moved to conceal her mother's guilt, even offering up her own brother as a sacrificial lamb.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: But I'm telling the truth. My mother is innocent.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: The truth is based in fact -- not emotion.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: The truth, sir, is the truth. Not what you choose to make of it.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: If there are no further questions the witness may stand down.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You've got to believe me.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: Please call your next witness, Mr. Aiken. Anna remains in the witness box.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Miss Surratt, you are dismissed. Anna tentatively begins to leave the witness box. She loo to her mother. Mary looks back with disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Your honor, everyone else I wish to call has either been silenced by jail or the threat of one.  90.

dialogues.speaker: HAMILTON
dialogues.text: (asides to Baker) Distoyalty surrounds itself with disloyal friends. Anna overhears Hamilton on her way to the door

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: I take it then the defense rests. Aiken glances at Mary. She won't even look at him. Aiken turns back towards General Hunter -- and nods. Anna holds moment at the door, devastated. As she exits, we CUT TO - ...A SALMON flipping for its life inside a WICKER CREEL.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: As JOHN SURRATT sits mournfully beside his fishing basket the opened ENVELOPE in hand, flapping in the wind.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: After the most thorough investigation in our nation's history...

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: As Aiken begins his closing argument.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: ...the government's entire case against Mary Surratt rests on three acts alone: The courtroom is rapt -- Baker, Catherine, even Hamilton.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: 1.) That she befriended John Wilkes Booth and his fellow Conspirators; 2.) That she carried a package from Booth with "instructions" the day of the assassination; and 3.) That she failed to recognize the prisoner, Lewis Payne, at the time of her arrest. Aiken rises from his chair.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: By themselves, these three acts constitute no crime. You, or I, might've done the same. But the prosecution insists she did so with evil intent -- largely on the testimony of two witnesses: Louis Wiechmann and John Lloyd. Aiken glances at WIECHMANN and LLOYD in the Gallery.  91.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yet, all the facts suggest they should be on trial. At best, their own actions undermine their credibility. At worst, they've done the unspeakable -- gained their freedom by falsely accusing another of their crime. (crossing the courtroom) But let there be no doubt why Mary Surratt is here today. It is because of one person: her son, John. (his back to Mary) John Surratt invited Booth and his associates into her home. She did not. And he hid the rifles and ammunition inside Lloyd's tavern. Not her. Aiken spots Reverdy, who nods his approval.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If John Surratt was part of this conspiracy, I hope he receives every punishment known to man. But if Mary Surratt can be convicted on such insufficient evidence, then none of us is safe. Aiken pauses in front of Baker and Hamilton.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: To preserve the Union, I'd have given my life. Now, I find myself without a side. Neither with the North or against the South. My friends have become foes -- my enemies, allies. (looks at Hamilton) But to abide by our Constitution is not a question of latitude and longitude -- North or South. It's about what kind of nation are we. One ruled by laws? Or by the fury of our People? Aiken examines a picture of Lincoln.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What enemy should we fear most? Lincoln was asked. Will it come from Europe, Africa or Asia? No, he replied. If we're to be destroyed, it'll be from within. By failing to rotect our Constitution and its aws. He puts the image of Lincoln back down.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: So, if we are willing to die on the battlefield defending our nation against a hostile force... then we, (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AIKEN foonT'd) too, must safeguard our founding principles with our lives. (a beat) Above all, we must never sacrifice our sacred rights -- out of a desire for revenge -- when so many have given their lives to preserve them. Aiken returns to his seat, and glances at Mary. A small n expresses her gratitude. Out of the corner of his eye, Ai spots Catherine, who is visibly moved.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Gentlemen. One bullet may have killed our beloved President. Holt begins his rebuttal.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: One bullet, but not one man! We close on a WIDE SHOT of the CROWDED courtroom. .

dialogues.speaker: SLOW DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: The same WIDE SHOT of the courtroom, only now it's EMPTY indicating the TRIAL is OVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of nature fills the secluded log cabin. John Surratt leans over a DESK with a bottle of BOURBON b as he agonizes over what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aiken enters.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: They're still deliberating. It's a good sign. Mary says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I went after your son like that. I felt I had no choice. After several moments.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: How 'bout we forget about the trial for a while? Aiken nods, pulls a deck of cards from his jacket pocket.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Surely, there must be others you'd prefer to play with.  93.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I've lost my seat at the card table.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I reckon' that's true. She takes the cards from Aiken's hands. MARY fen >) Both my father and husband went to their eternal rest without a dime cause of these fifty-two.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Perhaps, you'd fancy this instead? He withdraws a flask from his undercoat, which he smuggle inside. She takes the flask. MARY ; I fancy both -- straight up and seven card stud. And she starts shuffling -- like a pro.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hopefully, my luck's about to change. What are we wagering?

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Always the clothes on our backs. A beat. Then Mary smiles. Aiken finds a spot across from her, on the floor. As she starts to deal, we hear --

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY COMMISSION, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (shouting, in unison) Aye! . NINE HANDS raised high in the air

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: As the NINE MEMBERS of the Military Commission are seated around a long dinner table with General Hunter at the hea

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER
dialogues.text: Well then, we're all agreed on the penalty of death for the prisoners -- Herold, Atzerodt and Payne. a beat) What about the woman? Several Generals are barely payin eattention as they feas on prime rib. GENERAL WALLACE, Â© perpetually sketching judge, draws a CHARIOT RACE on his place setting.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HUNTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Regarding Mary Surratt. How many in favor, Gentleman?  94.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Damn it, Joseph! I told you she must be punished to the full extent.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: SECRETARY STANTON is irate. HOLT attempts to appease him.

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: Only four of the nine agreed with our recommendation. The majority avored a more merciful sentence - life in prison - on account of her age and sex.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: How else will her son surrender if he's not forced to offer his life for hers?

dialogues.speaker: HOLT
dialogues.text: I understand, sir. Unfortunately, the Generals' minds are already made.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Perhaps, not. A long beat. Stanton's EYES remain hard and cold.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This Yank' up North comes home after chopping some wood...

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: Aiken and Mary have now shared a few -- jokes and drinks.

dialogues.speaker: MARY,
dialogues.text: ..Says to his wife, "Honey, my hands are freezing." (Aiken takes a drink) "Put 'em between my thighs, " she replies, "That'll warm â€˜em up." Aiken freezes mid-gulp.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: After lunch, he goes out and chops some more wood. Says, "Sweetheart, my hands are really freezing!" "Well, put 'em between mk) thighs," (Mary downs her drin Before bed, the Yank' aed out one more time to get 'em through the night. "Dear, my hands are frozen, he says as he walks back inside. For goodness sake," his wife replies, "don't your ears ever get cold?" Aiken spits his drink. Both he and Mary enjoy the moment. Mary's smile slowly disappears.  95.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He hates me.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: My son. It wasn't Lincoln he despised. It was me.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I don't follow.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I refused to have him turn out like his father. I wouldn't let him out of my sight. Kept him so close I made him sit out the entire War. Finally, he got the courage to break free, and become what he always wanted - what you are, Frederick.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Your own man. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go to her. Off Aiken's confusion, Mary says solemnly --

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm not looking forward to it. But I'm ready for what they have in store for me. Anna is not.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: I'm not leaving you.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Please, Frederick. She's not as strong as she thinks. Off Aiken taking this in -- INTERCUT: Shiny DRESS SHOES with worn RIDING BOOTS. Crossing cobblestone. Traversing prison grounds. Ascending wooden steps. Climbing a steel staircase. A painted FRONT DOOR swings open...

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: Revealing Aiken, in dress shoes, standing in the doorway. Anna, her eyes swollen red with tears, averts Aiken's eye And then an IRON GATE pivots on its hinges...  96.

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: Revealing a SOLDIER, barely 19, in riding boots. Mary loo him in the eye, as he begins reading aloud from a documen

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG SOLDIER
dialogues.text: After mature consideration of the evidence... As_we INTERCUT from dmage- to- image, accompanied by the Soldier reading the verdict --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senator Johnson pulls a well-worn PAMPHLET off his shelf.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG SOLDIER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...The Commission finds the said accused -- Mary Eugenia Jenkins Surratt... As we CUT TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Surratt pours himself another drink.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG SOLDIER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...GUILTY of conspiring to kill and murder Abraham Lincoln, President of the United Sates and Commander -in- Chief of the Army and Navy... As we CUT BACK TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aiken follows Anna in as she attempts to conceal her dist

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG SOLDIER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...GUILTY of conspiring to kill and murder, Andrew Johnson, Vice President of the United States... As we CUT TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baker, Hamilton and pals exit the Club joking and laughin They are met by Catherine and several girlfriends.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG SOLDIER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...GUILTY of conspiring to kill and murder, William H. Seward, Secretary of State of the United States... As we CUT BACK TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary's stoic expression remains unchanged.  97.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG SOLDIER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...The Commission does, therefore, sentence you, Mary Surratt... The Soldier stops, looks up at Mary before continuing, as quickly CUT from one image to another -- -- Reverdy reading from the Constitution... -- John Surratt downing his drink... | -- Aiken and Anna remain in silence, her back to him... And then we CUT BACK TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary calmly nods for the Soldier to continue reading. YOUNG SOLDIER (V.O. ...TO be hanged by the neck unti she be dead. Mary maintains her "face" until the Young Soldier exits.. then buckles, just a bit, from what she's just been told. As we CUT BACK TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna and Aiken remain in silence for several beats. Final Aiken says softly...

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: You were in love with Booth. That's why you didn't burn his photo. After a moment...

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I swear I had no idea what he was capable of. We HOLD ON Anna, as we CUT TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Surratt storms inside as Anna, in an apron with her hair up, is preparing supper.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN SURRATT
dialogues.text: Booth is crazy. He's gonna get us into trouble -- or worse.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Calm down, John. Just tell me what happened.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN SURRATT
dialogues.text: He told me to pack a bag. He didn't say where I'm going. He just insists I leave town tonight.  98.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Ok. Then go pack your bag.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN SURRATT
dialogues.text: Ma won't let me go -- even if I wanted.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: What he's fighting for... what we're fighting for is more important than any of us.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN SURRATT
dialogues.text: Richmond's fallen. The War is over

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: The War is far from over, John. There's still much we can do! (John doesn't budge) Don't be like Pa. Have the courage to see something through. John angrily turns away, and storms up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Impressive. Anna is startled. Booth is standing in the kitchen doorwa

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Mr. Booth.

dialogues.speaker: _ BOOTH
dialogues.text: Anna. Looking as lovely as ever.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: "Lovely". Indeed, you are a fine actor. Anna removes her apron in an attempt to make herself presentable.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How long have you been there?

dialogues.speaker: BOOTH
dialogues.text: Long enough to know the Cause would be better off with more like you.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Booth. That's a compliment I will accept. There is an undeniable chemistry here. Off-screen, Mary and her son are in a heated conversation (NOTE: The rest of this scene is familiar from earlier in the script -- only we saw it from Mary's POV, not Anna's.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There's nothing more you can do.  99.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN SURRATT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The war is far from over, Mother And there's still much I can do!

dialogues.speaker: BOOTH
dialogues.text: Does he not have an original thought?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Think what you will, Mr. Booth, but he's still my brother.

dialogues.speaker: BOOTH
dialogues.text: My apologies, Miss Surratt. I'll see to it he makes you proud.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: John, please.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN SURRATT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Unhand me, Mother. Suddenly, there is a CRASH upstairs. Silence follows. Ann moves towards the stairs, but Booth grabs her arm. BOOTH. (shouts upstairs) John, are you coming or not? Moments later, John Surratt comes down the stairs, a pack bag in hand. He blows past Anna, and says to Booth.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN SURRATT
dialogues.text: Let's go. Booth and Anna exchange a look. Booth follows John Surrat out the front door. Several moments later Mary comes down the stairs. She is bleeding from a cut above her eye. Off Mary exchanging a long look with Anna, we CUT BACK TO

dialogues.speaker: PRESENT TIME
dialogues.text: Anna, tears now streaking her face, is holding a WANTED P featuring John Surratt.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: it should be my face on this -- not is. Aiken remains silent.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am such a coward. He's my younger brother. I should've protected him. But instead, I pushed him into it.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: You didn't know exactly what you were pushing him into.  100.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I know now. And yet I still told you where to find him, and damned im on the stand.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: You did so to save your mother. ANNA ; They need to know what I did.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: To what end? Because it will help your mother none.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: But it's the truth.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Does she know? Anna nods.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then no one else needs to. And Aiken turns for the door, and exits, leaving Anna alo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aiken begins to descend the steps. He hesitates a moment thinks on it, and then continues on his way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, at her cell window, soaks in the late afternoon sunlight, as we hear, off screen --

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: As a DOZEN CUSTOMERS surround a PAPER BOY, who is chantin the headlines aloud, almost gleefully.

dialogues.speaker: PAPER BOY
dialogues.text: Mary Surratt To Meet Her Doom.. Four Assassins Die Tomorrow at Noon Aiken happens upon the excitement, still unaware. As the crowd slowly parts, the headline is revealed to him:

dialogues.speaker: FOUR CONSPIRATORS TO BE EXECUTED
dialogues.text: Herold, Atzerodt, Payne

dialogues.speaker: MARY SURRATT
dialogues.text: Others Get Prison Terms  101. Aiken looks up from the paper and spots Catherine -- alon with his mates -- across the street. Aiken takes off. Only Catherine sees him scurrying away. While the others chatter about the impending executions, Catherine remains apart, with a look of dismay, as we cut FULL SCREEN: Of a ROCK, wrapped with the latest newspaper surrounded by shattered GLASS...

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK
dialogues.text: Revealing Anna, slumped, sobbing, with the rock beside he It's clear she's now heard the news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aiken, in disbelief. Reverdy Johnson is behind his desk

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Mudd, Arnold and O'Laughlin got life in prison instead of death. And Spangler only a half a dozen years.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Stanton doesn't want their sons. Any word from hers? Aiken shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: qhen there's nothing more you can oO.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: There has to be something.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Fred, you ve done everything you ossibly could. Better than I would ave done. But your only allegiance now must be to yourself.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: There are at least a dozen grounds on which to appeal this verdict.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: And you know there's no appealing it. That's why Stanton tried her in a military court.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: What about petitioning the President for a stay? _. REVERDY JOHNSON ; The President signed the execution order. It's over.  102.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: Can you get me in to see him? I'll plead her case directly... Reverdy cuts him off.

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
dialogues.text: If John Surratt won't sacrifice himself, son, why should you? She's not your mother.

dialogues.speaker: AIKEN
dialogues.text: And you're not my father.

dialogues.speaker: CHOIR BOY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Colonel Aiken? A CHOIR BOY, 12, is standing in the doorway. Aiken nods.

dialogues.speaker: CHOIR BOY
dialogues.text: This here's for you. The Boy passes him a NOTE. Aiken quickly reads it, then grabs his jacket and heads for the door

dialogues.speaker: REVERDY JOHNSON
